Abrin is structurally and functionally similar to viperine snake venom, making it extremely toxic even in small amounts. Its presence in the seeds of Abrus precatorius is a significant point of study, particularly in cases of accidental or intentional poisoning.

 

 

Abrus precatorius/ ratti seeds

 

Note - 'Sui' needles are traditionally crafted from Rati seeds, is traditional method to kill animals.

 

Explanation:


Option B. Dhatura: Contains tropane alkaloids, which are different from the toxalbumin found in viperine snake venom.


Option C. Ergot: Produced by a fungus and contains alkaloids that affect the nervous system, distinct from viperine venom.
 

Option D. Croton tiglium: Contains phorbol esters that cause irritation and purgation, but are not similar to viperine snake venom.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Nature of Poison –

 

  • Ideal homicidal poison: Thallium. Commonly used: arsenic and aconite
  • Ideal suicidal poison: Opium, barbiturates. Most commonly used: Organophosphorus compounds and endrin
  • Stupefying agents: Datura, cannabis, chloral hydrate
  • Cattle poison: Abrus, oleander, calotropis, aconite, arsenic, strychnine.
  • Aphrodisiac: Cantharides, cocaine, cannabis, opium, strychnine, arsenic.
  • Abortifacient: Calotropis, oleander, ergot, lead, aconite.
  • Arrow poison: Abrus, curare, snake venom, strychnine, calotropis.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 555

questions.text: In a forensic toxicology class, a medical officer is discussing the toxic properties of various plants. One topic of discussion is the marking nut, a plant known for its toxic effects. What is the active ingredient found in the marking nut that is responsible for its toxic properties?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Semecarpol

 

Option A:

 

The marking nut (bhilawa), derived from the plant Semecarpus anacardium, contains the active ingredient semecarpol. This compound is responsible for the nut's toxic and irritant properties, making it a subject of interest. When the juice is applied to the skin, it causes irritation, itching and a painful blister containing acrid serum and eczematous eruptions of the surrounding skin. The lesion resembles a bruise. Later on, an ulcer may be produced with sloughing. Constitutional symptoms such as fever, painful micturition with brown color urine may be seen.

 

Explanation:


Option B. Croton: Contains phorbol esters.
 

Option C. Abrin: Found in Abrus precatorius (Jequirity bean).
 

Option D. Ricin: Found in Ricinus communis (castor bean).

 

Educational Objective:


Semecarpol as the active ingredient in the marking nut (Semecarpus anacardium).

 

Medico-legal Aspects –

 

  • It may be used by malingerers to produce conjunctivitis or to support a false charge of assault; lesions produced simulate bruises
  • Accidental poisoning may result from the administration of juice by quacks for treatment of rheumatic pain and worm infestation.
  • Juice may be introduced into the vagina, as a punishment for infidelity.
  • For criminal abortion, juice is applied to the cervical os by means of abortion stick.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 556-557

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with multiple bruises on her arms and legs. She denies any history of trauma or abuse. The bruises appear unusual in color and distribution. During the examination, the patient seems evasive when discussing the origin of the bruises. A forensic expert is consulted, suspecting the possibility of artificially produced injuries. Which substance is known to be used for producing artificial bruises?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Marking nut

 

Option B:

 

The marking nut is known for its ability to produce artificial bruises due to its irritant properties. When applied to the skin, compounds in the marking nut can cause inflammation and discoloration, mimicking the appearance of a bruise. This property is sometimes exploited to fabricate evidence of physical abuse.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Capsicum: while this cause skin irritation and vesication, causes lacrimation, burning pain and redness if thrown in eyes, it is not typically used to produce artificial bruises.

 

Option C. Croton: Croton oil can cause severe burning, skin irritation and blistering but is not commonly used for creating artificial bruises. On ingestion, there is hot burning pain from the mouth to stomach, salivation, nausea, vomiting, purging, vertigo and bloody stools with severe griping pain, followed by prostration, circulatory and respiratory collapse and death.

 

Option D. Rati: Rati (Abrus precatorius) seeds are toxic and commonly used as cattle poison, when extract of seeds is injected under the skin with Sui, the symptoms resemble viperine snakebite and leads to inflammation, edema, oozing of hemorrhagic fluid from site of puncture and necrosis may occur. Tetanic convulsions occur or the animal becomes cold, drowsy or comatose and dies.

 

Educational Objective:


Artificial Bruise Vs True Bruise

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 556-557

questions.text: A medical officer is examining a group of agricultural workers from a chili processing factory at a community health center. The workers present with a common complaint of persistent burning sensation and redness on their hands. This condition, informally known in the local community as "Hunan hand," appears to be an occupational hazard. Considering their line of work and the symptoms, which plant is most likely causing this dermatological condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Capsicum

 

Option B:

 

"Hunan hand" is a type of contact dermatitis commonly seen in individuals who handle capsicum, particularly chili peppers. The condition is caused by the irritant effects of capsaicin, the active compound in chili peppers, which leads to burning sensations and skin irritation on the hands of those who frequently handle these plants.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Abrus precatorius: seeds are toxic and commonly used as cattle poison, when extract of seeds is injected under the skin with Sui, the symptoms resemble viperine snakebite and leads to inflammation, edema, oozing of hemorrhagic fluid from site of puncture and necrosis may occur. Tetanic convulsions occur or the animal becomes cold, drowsy or comatose and dies.

 

Option C. Dhatura: Signs and symptoms can be summarized as 9 Ds - Dryness of the mouth, Dysphagia, Dysarthria, Dilatation of cutaneous blood vessels, Diplopia, Dry hot skin, Drunken gait, Delirium and Drowsiness.

 

Option D. Strychnine: Extracted from the Strychnos nux-vomica tree and is highly toxic, but not related to the dermatological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

‘Hunan hand’ (‘Chilli Willy’) is a painful contact dermatitis seen in people with continuous and prolonged exposure to chilli peppers containing capsaicin. This is paradoxical to the use of capsaicin as local application for relief of pain in various conditions like diabetic neuropathy and postherpetic neuralgia.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 556

questions.text: A forensic expert is delivering a lecture on the identification of venomous snakes at a medical college. The expert notes that certain physical characteristics are commonly associated with poisonous snakes. However, one characteristic listed is not typical of venomous snakes. Which of the following characteristics is not generally true for poisonous snakes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Belly scales are small

 

Option B:

 

In venomous snakes, the presence of fangs and grooved teeth are adaptations for delivering venom, and small head scales are a common feature. However, the size of belly scales in  venomous snakes is large and cover the entire breadth of belly.

 

 

 

Some important Pointers are

 

  • Poisonous snakes, e.g. King cobra (Ophiophagus hannah), common cobra (Naja naja), Russells viper (Daboia rusellii), saw-scaled viper (Echis carinatae), pit viper and krait (Bungarus caeruleus).

  • Non-poisonous snakes, e.g. rat snake, vine snake, sand boa and mud snake.

  • In tropical regions of the world including India, most of the snakebite cases are caused by four venomous snakes often referred to as big four snakescommon cobra, common krait, Russells viper and saw scaled viper.

  • Russells viper is considered one of the most deadly land dwelling snakes on earth.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fangs present: Fangs are a key feature of venomous snakes, these  are long and canalized, like hypodermic needle, used to inject venom.
 

Option C. Small head scales: Many venomous snakes have small head scales, which is a common characteristic of Viper. Large scales are seen with pit viper, cobra and krait
 

Option D. Grooved teeth: Grooved or hollow teeth are often present in venomous snakes for venom delivery.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Poisonous Vs non-poisonous snakes

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 559

questions.text: In a forensic toxicology training session at a medical college, the instructor is discussing the different types of snake venoms and their effects. One topic is the type of snakebite that predominantly causes hematologic abnormalities, such as coagulopathy and bleeding disorders. Based on this information, which snake's venom is most likely to cause these hematologic issues?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Viper

 

Option C:


Vipers are known for their venom's hematologic effects, including causing coagulopathy and bleeding disorders. Their venom contains enzymes that disrupt the blood clotting mechanisms, leading to bleeding manifestations and making viper bites particularly dangerous in terms of hematological abnormalities.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cobra: Primarily neurotoxic, affecting the nervous system rather than causing hematologic issues.


Option B. Krait: Also neurotoxic, with venom that leads to neurological symptoms but not predominantly hematologic abnormalities.


Option D. Sea snake: Venom affects muscles (myotoxic) and kidneys but does not primarily cause hematologic abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurotoxic Vs vasculotoxic venom

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 562

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department of a district hospital in India with a history of sudden onset muscle weakness, ptosis, and difficulty breathing. He reports being bitten by a snake while walking through his farm at night. The emergency medical officer notes two small puncture wounds on his ankle. The patient's condition rapidly deteriorates, necessitating intubation and mechanical ventilation. The medical officer suspects envenomation by a common Indian krait. Considering the severity of symptoms, what is the estimated lethal dose of krait venom for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6 mg

 

Option B:

 

Signs and symptoms are similar to cobra poisoning, but less rapid. Abdominal pain, ptosis, dysarthria, dysphagia, chest pain, quadriparesis, respiratory paralysis and death may occur. There is no nausea and froth, but drowsiness is more. Common krait hunt nocturnally and are quick to bite people sleeping on the floor, often without waking their victims since the venom is painless. Bites would show symptoms within the first 6 hr.  Victims wake up later, paralyzed or die in their sleep.

 

Bite mark - Two fang marks, with or without small marks of other teeth.

 

 

Krait venom is highly potent, and a dose as low as 6 mg can be lethal in humans. The venom contains neurotoxins that lead to paralysis by blocking neurotransmitter release at the neuromuscular junction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fatal Doses -

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 564

questions.text: A medical officer is conducting training on snake envenomation and its clinical manifestations. When discussing the Elapidae family of snakes, which includes cobras and kraits, the officer emphasizes a particular symptom as the most characteristic feature of their envenomation. What is this most characteristic feature?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neuro-paralytic symptoms

 

Option B:

 

The Elapidae family, which includes snakes like cobras and kraits, is known for venom that primarily causes neuro-paralytic symptoms. The neurotoxins in their venom can lead to paralysis, difficulty in breathing, and, if not treated, can be fatal due to respiratory failure.

 

Note –

 

  • Many bites by the poisonous snakes are dry bites implying that the snakes fail to inject the venom. In general, about 70% of bites are due to non-poisonous snakes, and of the rest, 15% are dry bites and only 15% bites cause envenomation.
  • About 80% of venomous snake bite in India is by saw-scaled viper. The likelihood of a ‘dry bite’ is most common with a cobra.
  • Early and intense pain implies significant envenomation.
  • Local signs and symptoms: Fang marks, pain, bleeding, bruising, lymphangitis, lymph node enlargement, inflammation, blistering, local infection, abscess formation and necrosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bleeding manifestation: More typical of vipers, not Elapidae snakes.
 

Option C. Rhabdomyolysis: Not a primary symptom of Elapidae envenomation.
 

Option D. Cardiotoxicity: While possible, it is not the most characteristic feature of Elapidae venom.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Signs and symptoms of elapinae and viperine bite -

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 562 -563

questions.text: In a workshop focusing on snakebite management, a medical officer discusses the use of pressure immobilization techniques for venomous snakebites. A question arises about the optimal pressure to be applied in cases of envenomation by Elapidae snakes, like cobras or kraits. What is the recommended ligature pressure for such cases to effectively resist the spread of the venom?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50–70 mm Hg

 

Option C:

 

The recommended ligature pressure for a pressure bandage in the case of Elapidae snakebites is 50–70 mm Hg. This pressure is effective in slowing the lymphatic spread of venom without compromising arterial blood flow and potentially causing tissue damage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. < 10 mm Hg: Insufficient pressure to effectively slow down the spread of venom.
 

Option B. 20–30 mm Hg: May not provide enough pressure to significantly impede venom movement.
 

Option D. > 100 mm Hg: Excessively high pressure that can obstruct blood flow and cause tissue damage and gangrene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pressure immobilization is recommended for elapid and sea-snake bites, but not for viper bites as it may cause local necrosis. It should be tight enough to occlude the superficial venous and lymphatic return, but not the arterial or deep venous flow. A pressure of 50 to 70 mm Hg is maintained.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 564

questions.text: A medical officer at a hospital is discussing unusual symptoms of different types of poisoning. One of the topics is priapism, a condition characterized by a persistent and painful erection. The officer is highlighting various causes of this symptom. Which of the following is a known cause of priapism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cantharides poisoning

 

Option C:

 

Priapism is a known complication of cantharide poisoning. Cantharides, found in substances like "Spanish Fly," are known for their irritant properties, particularly to the urogenital tract, leading to symptoms like priapism.

 

Cantharidin Poisoning –

 

Signs and Symptoms - 

 

  • Externally, on application to the skin, redness and burning pain are produced which is followed by formation of vesicles.
  • On ingestion, there is burning sensation in the mouth, throat and abdomen, nausea and vomiting of bloodstained material, pain in abdomen, severe thirst, tenesmus and difficulty in swallowing and speech. Later, a dull pain is felt in the loins, desire to micturate, but urine is scanty and bloodstained. Priapism in males and abortion in pregnant females may occur. The patient becomes prostrated with convulsions, and coma preceding death.

 

Fatal dose: 15–30 mg of cantharidin or 1.5 g of powder.

 

Fatal period: 24 h.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. Snake bite: While some snake venoms can affect blood clotting, they are not typically associated with priapism.
 

Option B. Rati poisoning: This plant's poisoning primarily causes symptoms like vomiting, diarrhea, and convulsions, but not priapism.
 

Option D. Arsenic poisoning: Arsenic poisoning leads to symptoms like abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and cardiac issues, but it does not cause priapism.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Priapism is a condition of persistent painful erection of penis which is seen in phosphorus and cantharide poisoning.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 558

choices.text: Applying a loose bandage to occlude lymphatic flow
Making an incision over the wound
Reassuring the patient to reduce anxiety
Immobilizing the bitten limb

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to an emergency department after a suspected snakebite in a rural area. The medical officer notes puncture marks on the patient’s lower leg. In discussing the immediate treatment plan with the medical team, the officer emphasizes several key steps in snakebite management. However, one of the suggested interventions is outdated and potentially harmful. Which of the following interventions should NOT be included in the treatment of this snakebite?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Making an incision over the wound

 

Option B:

 

Making an incision over a snakebite wound, once a common practice, is now strongly discouraged as it can increase the risk of infection and bleeding without offering any proven benefit in removing venom.

 

Assessment of severity of envenomation –

 

 

Local Treatment (First aid) 

 

  • Assure the patient.
  • Apply loose pressure over the bitten area, which delays absorption of venom
  • Pressure immobilization is recommended for elapid and sea-snake bites, but not for viper bites as it may cause local necrosis. It should be tight enough to occlude the superficial venous and lymphatic return, but not the arterial or deep venous flow. A pressure of 50 to 70 mm Hg is maintained.
  • Immobilize the limb, as movement can accelerate the spread of venom.
  • Clean the wound with soap and water, or iodine and cover with a sterile dressing (but not much of use).
  • Make the patient lie on one side in the recovery position so that the airway is clear, in case of vomiting or fainting.
  • If a patient is brought after few hours (4 to 6) of snake bite with mild local swelling and no systemic symptoms, he should be kept under observation for 24 hours, closely monitored for vital signs, cardiac system, and oxygen saturation, given tetanus toxoid and discharged.

 

NOT TO BE DONE –

 

  • Local incision and suction can cause local bleeding and nerve injury.
  • Suck venom out of the wound.
  • Apply chemicals or medicines on the wound.
  • Cauterized the wound, as it seals the poison within the tissues.
  • Cryotherapy

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. Applying a loose bandage can help slow the spread of venom through the lymphatic system, but the disadvantage is venom is in the limbs for long hours, leads to severe local reaction especially in vasculotoxic poison. Can be applied in case of neurotoxic poisons.
 

Option C. Reassuring the patient is crucial in managing shock and stress, which can exacerbate the situation.
 

Option D. Immobilizing the bitten limb helps to reduce the spread of venom through the body. (should be kept below the heart level)

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 564 -565

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is admitted to a district hospital following a snakebite. He was working in his field when he felt a sudden sharp pain in his leg. On examination, the medical officer notes significant swelling and blistering around the bite site, extending up the leg. The patient also shows signs of systemic involvement, including altered mental status and difficulty breathing. Given the severity of the envenomation, what is the initial dose of antivenom that should be administered?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 10 vials

 

Explanation:

 

The lyophilized polyvalent antisnake venom (ASV) serum: This serum is effective against common poisonous snakes in India, including cobra, common krait, saw-scaled viper, and Russell's viper.

 

Dose Administration: The ASV is freeze-dried and dissolved in water, typically a 10 ml vial. Around 100 ml of this serum should be diluted in 200-500 ml of isotonic saline for slow intravenous (IV) administration.

 

Recommended Initial Dose:  The initial dose of ASV is recommended to be 10 vials, administered via IV over about 1 hour.

 

Repeat Doses: For vasculotoxic species (like Russell's viper), repeat doses depend on the 6-hour rule, guided by the coagulation profile, with a maximum recommended dose of 30 vials. For neurotoxic species (like cobra and krait), the repeat dose is based on a 1–2-hour rule, depending on patient improvement or worsening, with a maximum dose of 20 vials.

 

Indications for Antivenom: Systemic envenoming (e.g., spontaneous bleeding, coagulopathy, thrombocytopenia, CNS symptoms like ptosis, paralysis, CVS symptoms like hypotension, and acute renal failure), and local envenoming (e.g., swelling involving more than half of the bitten limb, rapid extension of swelling, enlarged tender lymph nodes).

 

Urgency and Contraindications: Antivenom treatment should be administered as soon as indicated. There are no absolute contraindications to ASV treatment. However, it should not be used indiscriminately due to risks of severe adverse reactions, cost, and limited supply.

 

Observation Post-Administration: Patients must be closely observed for at least 1 hour after starting IV antivenom to detect early anaphylactic reactions.

 

Dosing for Children: Children should receive the same dose of ASV as adults, as snakes inject the same amount of venom into both children and adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial dosing of antivenom in severe snake envenomation should be sufficient to neutralize the venom effectively. A starting dose of 10 vials is recommended in cases with significant systemic involvement, followed by careful monitoring and additional doses as needed. The goal is to use the minimum effective amount of antivenom to reduce the risk of adverse reactions while ensuring effective treatment.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 564

choices.text: Type II hypersensitivity reactions
Type III hypersensitivity reactions
Type IV hypersensitivity reactions
Type V hypersensitivity reactions

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer is brought to a primary health center after being bitten by a snake. He is treated with antisnake venom (ASV). The medical officer advises the nursing staff to closely monitor the patient for potential adverse reactions to the ASV. Based on the nature of ASV and its immunological properties, which type of hypersensitivity reaction is most likely to occur following its administration?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type III hypersensitivity reactions

 

Option B:

 

Antisnake venom (ASV) can cause Type III hypersensitivity reactions, also known as immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity. This occurs when the antibodies in the ASV form immune complexes with antigens, leading to complement activation and an inflammatory response. This can manifest as serum sickness, presenting with symptoms like fever, rash, arthralgia, and lymphadenopathy, usually a few days after the administration of ASV.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Type II hypersensitivity reactions: These are antibody-mediated reactions against cell surface or matrix antigens, which is not the typical mechanism of ASV reactions.

 

Option C. Type IV hypersensitivity reactions: Also known as delayed-type hypersensitivity, these reactions involve T-cell-mediated responses and are not commonly associated with ASV.

 

Option D. Type V hypersensitivity reactions: This category, which includes stimulatory hypersensitivity, is not a mechanism associated with ASV reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antivenom reactions:

 

  • Anaphylactic or type I (immediate) hypersensitivity reactions may develop (itching, urticaria, glottis edema, wheezing, cough, nausea, vomiting, fever and tachycardia). Adrenaline, 0.5–1.0 ml of 0.1% solution (1 in 1000, 1 mg/ml) is given subcutaneously in adults; in children the dose is 0.01 ml/kg.
  • Serum sickness is a type III (delayed) hypersensitivity reaction which is characterized by fever, urticaria, lymphadenopathy and arthritis, and may develop in 3 days to 3 weeks. Serum sickness is dose-related, as it occurs when > 8 vials of polyvalent ASV are administered.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 565

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: A 30-year-old hiker is brought to the emergency department approximately two hours after experiencing a scorpion sting. He complains of severe radiating pain at the sting site, along with nausea, headache, and blurred vision. The emergency medical team notes the presence of mild local swelling, reddening, and paresthesia. Given the patient's symptoms and the known properties of scorpion venom, which of the following best characterizes the action of this venom?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

Scorpion venom is a clear, colorless proteinous toxalbumen with both hemolytic and neurotoxic effects. Its action is characterized by potent autonomic stimulation, leading to massive release of catecholamines and direct myocardial effects. This makes it somewhat similar to the venoms of cobras, vipers, and kraits, which all have neurotoxic components, although each has distinct characteristics. Cobras and kraits have venoms with neurotoxic effects, while vipers' venom is more hemotoxic. However, the systemic effects of scorpion venom, including autonomic stimulation and cardiovascular impact, share similarities with all these snake venoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cobra: Shares neurotoxic effects with scorpion venom, but also has cytotoxic components.

 

Option B. Viper: Primarily hemotoxic but can cause systemic effects similar to scorpion venom.

 

Option C. Krait: Has neurotoxic venom, similar to scorpion venom, but lacks the hemolytic action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scorpion venom, known for its neurotoxic and hemolytic effects, shares similarities with the venoms of cobras, vipers, and kraits. Its potent autonomic stimulatory action, leading to systemic symptoms, is a key characteristic. Understanding these properties is crucial for the appropriate management of scorpion stings and snakebites.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 566

questions.text: In an emergency department, a medical officer is treating a patient who has been stung by a scorpion. The patient exhibits symptoms such as hypertension, severe pain, and cardiovascular disturbances. The medical officer is considering the administration of a specific drug to counteract these effects. Which drug is commonly used in the management of scorpion stings to alleviate these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prazosin

 

Option D:


Treatment of Scorpion Sting

 

  • The limb is immobilized, and a pressure bandage is applied proximal to the site of sting.
  • The site may be incised and washed with water or weak solution of ammonia, borax or KMnO4.
  • Prazosin therapy: Prazosin 30 μg/kg/dose (1 mg for adult, 500 μg for children) is given orally and then after every 3 hr till extremities are warm, dry and peripheral veins are visible.
  • Scorpion antivenom (SAV) is a specific antidote to scorpion venom. SAV against Indian red scorpion is available. Recovery is better by simultaneous administration of SAV and prazosin compared with prazosin alone.
  • Calcium gluconate 10 ml of 10% solution slow IV is given for pains, cramps and edema.
  • Barbiturates/chlorpromazine is given to sedate and control convulsion.
  • Atropine to prevent pulmonary edema.
  • Symptomatic treatment.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. EDTA: A chelating agent, not typically used for scorpion stings.
 

Option B. Neostigmine: An anticholinesterase agent, not the primary treatment for scorpion envenomation.
 

Option C. N-acetylcysteine: An antioxidant used mainly for acetaminophen toxicity, not scorpion stings.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Prazosin, an alpha-blocker, is effectively used in the treatment of scorpion stings. It helps in managing cardiovascular symptoms such as hypertension and myocardial dysfunction, which are common in severe scorpion envenomation cases. Prazosin works by blocking the alpha-adrenergic receptors, thereby reducing the severity of systemic symptoms caused by the venom.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 566

questions.text: During an autopsy conducted by a forensic expert at a medical college, the body of a 35-year-old male is examined. The individual was found deceased under suspicious circumstances, with drug paraphernalia nearby. Toxicology screening is underway, and the forensic expert is considering various substances that could have contributed to the death. The expert must identify which of the following substances found at the scene is NOT an opioid agonist, as this will help narrow down the cause of death and contribute to the medicolegal investigation.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ketamine

 

Option B:

 

Ketamine is not an opioid agonist; it is classified as a dissociative anesthetic and works primarily as an NMDA receptor antagonist. Unlike opioid agonists such as heroin, methadone, and fentanyl, which act on opioid receptors and are primarily used for pain relief and in addiction treatment, ketamine has a different mechanism of action and is used for its anesthetic and analgesic properties, as well as for treating certain cases of depression.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Heroin: Heroin is an opioid agonist (semi synthetic). It is converted to morphine in the body, which then binds to opioid receptors.

 

Option C. Methadone: It is a long-acting opioid, with a half-life of about 15 hours, which has all the physiologic properties of heroin. It is an analgesic more powerful than morphine. It can be given orally or parenterally. It used in pain management and in the treatment of opioid dependence.

 

Option D. Fentanyl: Fentanyl is a potent synthetic opioid agonist, 50 to 100 times more potent than morphine. It can be taken i.v., orally, smoked, snorted or as skin patches. Widely used for pain management and anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ketamine generally is a neuroprotective drug, can be used in treatment of nerve gas induce seizures, but also used as sedative or date rape (club) drug commonly known as “K, Ket, special K, super acid, smack K, kit-kat”. The common sign and symptoms induced due to ketamine are Dissociative anesthesia, confusion, hallucinations, impaired motor function, nystagmus, amnesia, sedation, respiratory depression.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 446

questions.text: A forensic medical officer is analyzing a case involving the death of an individual with multiple drugs present in their system. Part of the investigation involves understanding the pharmacological effects of various substances found at the scene to assess their contribution to the fatality. In this context, the officer is tasked with identifying which of the following substances has the least narcotic effect.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Papaverine

 

Option D:

 

Papaverine, a non-narcotic compound derived from the opium poppy, is used primarily as a smooth muscle relaxant and vasodilator. Unlike morphine and codeine, which are narcotics and have significant analgesic and sedative effects, and thebaine, which is a precursor to many opioids, papaverine does not have narcotic properties and is not used for pain relief or sedation.

 

Note - Papaverine is also used for evaluation of Penile function (in alleged cases of impotency & sterility)

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. Morphine: A potent narcotic with significant analgesic properties.
 

Option B. Codeine: A milder narcotic, often used for pain relief and as a cough suppressant.
 

Option C. Thebaine: Thebaine is a minor constituent of opium and is chemically similar to both morphine and codeine but is less narcotic and more stimulatory in nature.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Papaverine is a non-narcotic alkaloid used primarily for its muscle relaxant and vasodilator properties.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 584, 588

questions.text: In the emergency department of a hospital, a 28-year-old male is brought in by paramedics in a comatose state. The medical officer notes that the patient has pin-point pupils, reduced respiratory rate, and bradycardia. Considering these clinical signs, what is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Opioid poisoning

 

Option B:

 

Opioid Poisoning - sign and symptoms –

 

  1. Stage of Excitement: It is of short duration. There is euphoria, increased sense of well-being, freedom from anxiety, talkativeness and laughter. Hallucinations, flushing of face and rapid heart rate are seen.
  2. Stage of Stupor: Headache, nausea, vomiting, weakness, heaviness in limbs, giddiness, drowsiness, diminished sensibility and strong tendency to sleep from which the patient can be aroused by painful stimuli. Pupils are contracted, and face and lips are cyanosed. Pulse and respiration almost normal.
  3. Stage of Narcosis/Coma: Patient passes into deep coma from which he cannot be aroused. In this stage -
  • Muscles: Flaccid and relaxed
  • Face: Pale
  • Reflexes: Absent
  • Conjunctiva: Congested
  • Skin: Cold with profuse perspiration, all other secretions are suspended
  • Pupils: Constricted to pin-point, non-reacting
  • Blood pressure: Hypotension
  • Temperature: Hypothermia
  • Pulse: Weak, feeble
  • Respiration: Slow, stertorous (4–6 breaths/min)
  • Sphincter tone: Increased (can lead to urinary retention).

 

During the terminal stages, pink froth comes from the mouth, pulse is slow, irregular and imperceptible, respiration becomes Cheyne-Stokes, and ultimately deep coma and death due to respiratory depression and cardiorespiratory arrest.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tricyclic antidepressant poisoning: Typically causes anticholinergic symptoms like dilated pupils, not pin-point pupils.

 

Option C. Benzodiazepine poisoning: Can cause sedation and respiratory depression, but miosis is not a typical feature.

 

Option D. Organophosphorus poisoning: Usually presents with muscarinic symptoms like salivation and lacrimation, and typically causes pupillary constriction but is associated with other specific symptoms not observed here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of coma, pin-point pupils (miosis), reduced respiratory rate, and bradycardia strongly suggests opioid poisoning. Opioids are known to depress the central nervous system, leading to respiratory depression, reduced heart rate, and miosis, which are classic signs of opioid overdose.
 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 585

questions.text: In a rural health center, a medical officer is attending to a patient who was brought in with symptoms of opium overdose. The patient exhibits signs of respiratory depression, altered mental status, and pinpoint pupils. Given the clinical presentation and the urgent need to counteract the effects of opium, which medication is the medical officer most likely to administer as part of the emergency treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Naloxone

 

Option A:

 

Treatment of Opium Overdose –

 

  • Support vitals through respirator and other emergency procedures.
  • Decontamination: Stomach wash frequently with 1:5000 KMnO4 leaving some solution in stomach to oxidize the alkaloid that might be secreted in stomach after absorption. Lavage should be carried out even after IV/IM injection of drug, as it is secreted in the stomach.
  • Administer activated charcoal—method of choice for decontamination following ingestion.
  • Enema with 30 g of sodium sulfate twice daily.
  • Whole-bowel irrigation in body packers.
  • Antidote: Narcotic antagonist naloxone in an initial dose of 0.4–2 mg IV/IM repeated every 2–3 min up to 10 mg, if no response occurs.

 

If there is little response to naloxone alone, possibility of an overdose with a benzodiazepine should be considered, and a challenge with IV flumazenil, 0.2mg/min up to maximum of 3 mg in an hour might be used.

 

Explanation:
 

Option B. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug, mainly used to treat bradycardia and for certain types of nerve agent and pesticide poisonings, but not for opioid overdose.

 

Option C. Neostigmine: Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor used in the treatment of neuroparalytic symptoms in cobra envenomation, not for opioid overdose.

 

Option D. Physostigmine: Physostigmine is also a cholinesterase inhibitor and is used to treat anticholinergic toxicity, not opioid overdose.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Naloxone is an opioid antagonist that is commonly used to treat opioid (including opium) poisoning. It works by rapidly displacing opioids from their receptors, thereby reversing the effects of opioid overdose, such as respiratory depression and altered mental status.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 586

choices.text: Morphine (and other opioids) poisoning

questions.text: In a forensic toxicology lab, a technician is conducting a test to identify the presence of a specific substance in a sample from a poisoning case. The technician uses the Marquis test, which is a colorimetric test known for its specific reaction. This test is particularly used for detecting which type of poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Morphine (and other opioids) poisoning

 

Option C:

 

MARQUIS'S TEST: A drop of a mixture consisting of 3ml of concentrated sulphuric acid, and 3 drops of formalin added to a fragment of the suspected residue produces a purple-red color which gradually changes to violet and finally to blue.

 

It is a simple spot-test to presumptively identify alkaloids. It can be used to test cocaine, opiates and phenethylamines.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mercury poisoning: Acute mercury poisoning can be detected by measuring blood levels (> 10 μg/dl), whereas urine ( > 20 μg/l) and hair (>5 ppm) analysis help confirming chronic exposure. Urine and blood mercury levels are assessed by atomic absorption spectrophotometer. Mercury concentration of hair is best assessed by neutron activation analysis.

 

Option B. Arsenic poisoning: Detected through urine excretion (> 50 μg/l in 24 h) of arsenic or metabolites of arsenic including methylarsonic acid and dimethylarsenic acid; Blood (serum arsenic > 0.9 μg/dl), stool, liver, kidneys and bones also shows the presence of arsenic. As with all heavy metals, microcytic hypochromic anemia is common. Hair (Arsenic > 75 μg%) and Nails (> 100 μg%) is suggestive of poisoning.

 

Option D. Cyanide poisoning: The triad of lab findings is suggestive of cyanide poisoning:

 

  1. A narrow arterial-venous oxygen difference
  2. An anion gap metabolic acidosis
  3. An elevated lactate concentration.

 

Measurement of whole blood cyanide in an anticoagulant tube (not done with plasma or serum since cyanide is sequestered in RBCs) can confirm toxicity. HCN is also measured by gas chromatography or spectrophotometry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Marquis test is a colorimetric reagent test used primarily to detect the presence of alkaloids, particularly morphine and other opioids. When the Marquis reagent is added to a substance containing these opioids, it produces a distinct color change, which is a positive indication of their presence.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 586

questions.text: In a district hospital, a medical officer is examining a patient brought in by the police following a car accident. The patient displays signs of severe alcohol intoxication and is unconscious. The officer orders a blood ethanol concentration test, anticipating a high value. Based on standard toxicological knowledge, at what blood ethanol concentration is the risk of fatality generally considered to be high, which might be relevant for the medicolegal report of this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 300–400 mg/dl

 

Option D:

 

A blood ethanol concentration of 300 - 400 mg/dl is generally considered to be in the range where the risk of fatality is high. At these levels, central nervous system depression is severe, potentially leading to coma and respiratory failure, which are life-threatening conditions.

 

Fatal dose (non-addict) –

 

  • 150–250 ml of absolute alcohol consumed in 1 hr.
  • Risk of death is increased if BAC > 200 mg/dl, and death is typical if the BAC is between 300-400 mg/dl

 

Note - 210 g of alcohol in men and 140 g of alcohol in women per week are considered safe limits for drinking, if liver damage is to be avoided.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. 50–100 mg/dl: This range is typically associated with mild impairment but not usually life-threatening. The symptoms are - decreased inhibitions, increased self-confidence, decreased attention span, slurring of speech, mild incoordination, alteration of judgement, nystagmus.

 

Option B. 100–150 mg/dl: This concentration can cause moderate impairment, leads to some mental confusion, emotional instability, loss of critical judgement, ataxia, impaired memory, sleepiness, slowed reaction time.

 

Option C. 150–300 mg/dl: While this range indicates significant impairment and leads to loss of muscular coordination, staggering gait, marked mental confusion, drowsiness, exaggeration of emotions, dizziness, decreased pain response, disorientation; thickened speech.

 

Educational Objective:
 

High Blood Alcohol Concentration (BAC) and Physiological effects –

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 570

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of binge drinking during holidays presents to the cardiology clinic with palpitations and irregular heartbeats. He admits to recent heavy alcohol consumption over the weekend. The cardiologist is considering a diagnosis related to his drinking habits. Which cardiac condition is most commonly associated with excessive alcohol consumption, particularly in the context of "holiday heart syndrome"?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atrial fibrillation

 

Option A:

 

Patient may exhibit holiday heart syndrome in which cardiac dysrhythmias (especially atrial fibrillation and ventricular arrhythmias) are often observed after a heavy drinking episode. Hypoglycemia, gastritis, pancreatitis and toxic psychosis may also occur. In teenagers, it may lead to anemia, macrocytosis, and elevation of enzymes, bilirubin and uric acid.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Holiday heart syndrome is commonly associated with atrial fibrillation, particularly in individuals who engage in binge drinking. This syndrome can occur even in people without prior heart disease and is characterized by an irregular and rapid heartbeat, leading to symptoms like palpitations and potentially serious complications.

 

Ref: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology” Gautam Biswas. 3rd edition, Pg. 546

questions.text: At a rehabilitation center, a forensic expert is conducting a training session for medical officers on the pharmacological management of substance dependence. One topic of discussion is the use of Disulfiram. The expert asks the attendees to identify the substance dependence for which Disulfiram is specifically indicated as a treatment option.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alcohol dependence

 

Option A:

 

Antabuse (disulfiram) is given as an aversion technique. Disulfiram (tetraethyl thiuram disulfide) blocks metabolism of alcohol by inhibiting the acetaldehyde dehydrogenase enzyme, leads to accumulation of acetaldehyde in blood causing disulfiram-ethanol reaction (aldehyde syndrome).

 

Symptoms: Flushing, palpitation, nausea, vomiting, anxiety, tightness of chest, hypotension, sweating, throbbing headache, giddiness, sense of impending doom and abdominal cramps appear due to which patient dislikes alcohol.

 

Duration of the syndrome (1–4 hr) depends on the amount of alcohol consumed.

 

Dose: The initial dose is 250–500 mg for 1–2 weeks (taken before bedtime) followed by a maintenance dose of 250 mg/day (range 125–500 mg). The total daily dosage should not exceed 500 mg.

 

Contraindications: Coronary artery disease, liver failure, chronic renal failure, peripheral neuropathy, muscular disease, history of psychosis and pregnancy (1st trimester).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Heroin dependence: Typically treated with opioid agonists or partial agonists like methadone and buprenorphine, not Disulfiram.
 

Option C. Cocaine dependence: Often managed with behavioral therapies; Disulfiram is not a primary treatment.
 

Option D. Cannabis dependence: Treatment usually involves counseling and behavioral therapies, not Disulfiram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disulfiram is used in the treatment of alcohol dependence. It inhibits the enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to the accumulation of acetaldehyde when alcohol is consumed. This causes unpleasant symptoms such as flushing, headache, nausea, and vomiting, which act as a deterrent to drinking alcohol.

 

Note - Disulfiram-like reaction is also caused by metronidazole

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 573

questions.text: In a deaddiction center, a medical officer is conducting an assessment of a patient who has recently ceased heavy and prolonged alcohol use. The patient is exhibiting certain symptoms that are characteristic of alcohol withdrawal. Based on common clinical manifestations of alcohol withdrawal, the medical officer is determining the most frequently observed symptom in such cases. What symptom is most typically associated with alcohol withdrawal?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tremor

 

Option B:

 

Tremors are the most common and often one of the earliest symptoms of alcohol withdrawal. They are part of the alcohol withdrawal syndrome, which can range from mild symptoms like tremors and anxiety to severe complications like seizures and delirium tremens (an acute organic brain syndrome, usually seen within 2–4 days of complete absence from heavy alcohol drinking in chronic alcoholics, and most severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome)

 

Medico-legal Aspects related to Delirium Tremens –

 

  • It is a medical emergency and should be treated on an inpatient basis.
  • When a person in delirium tremens commits any illegal act, he is not held responsible by the reason that he/she is considered to be mentally unsound during this state (Sec. 84 IPC).

 

Explanation:


Option A. Body ache: While discomfort is common, it is not as specific or as prevalent as tremors.


Option C. Diarrhea: Diarrhea can occur in alcohol withdrawal, but it is not the most common symptom and is often related to other gastrointestinal disturbances due to alcohol abuse.

 

Option D. Convulsion: Convulsions or seizures can occur during alcohol withdrawal, particularly in severe cases, but they are less common than tremors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Withdrawal Symptoms of chronic alcoholism -

 

Tremulousness or shakes or jitters (most common sign), weakness, pain in muscle, cold sweat, insomnia, loss of appetite, vomiting, diarrhea, restlessness, exaggerated reflexes, raised temperature, fluctuating BP, hallucinations, loss of memory and delirium tremens. Many alcoholics experience ‘the shakes’ approximately 12–24 hr after their last drink. The shakes are tremors caused by over excitation of the CNS. Tremors may be accompanied by tachycardia, diaphoresis, anorexia, and insomnia. After 24–72 hr, the alcoholic may have ‘rum fits’ (i.e. generalized seizures).

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 580

questions.text: During a primary care consultation, a physician is assessing a patient's risk for a particular substance dependence. The physician decides to use the CAGE questionnaire, a brief screening tool. This questionnaire is specifically designed to screen for dependence on which substance?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alcohol dependence

 

Option A:

 

CAGE questionnaire: Developed by Dr John Ewing, an internationally used assessment instrument for identifying alcoholics. The questions are –

 

  1. Have you ever felt you should Cut down on your drinking?
  2. Have people Annoyed you, by criticizing your drinking?
  3. Have you ever felt bad or Guilty about your drinking?
  4. Have you ever had a drink, first thing in the morning, to steady your nerves or to get rid of a hangover (Eye opener)?

 

Scoring: Item responses on the CAGE are scored 0 or 1, with a higher score an indication of alcohol problems. A total score of 2 or greater is considered clinically significant.

 

Explanation:


Option B. Opiate poisoning, Option C. Dhatura poisoning and Option D.  Barbiturate poisoning: The CAGE questionnaire is not relevant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The CAGE questionnaire is a widely used screening tool for alcohol dependence. It consists of four questions aimed at identifying problematic drinking behaviors and the potential for alcohol dependence. The acronym CAGE stands for Cut down, Annoyed, Guilty, and Eye-opener, which are the key concepts addressed in the questions.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 572

questions.text: A 35-year-old male, with a history of chronic alcohol use, presents to the emergency department with seizures. He reports not having consumed alcohol for the past 2 days. What is the initial treatment of choice in this patient to manage his seizures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diazepam

 

Option A:

 

In a patient presenting with alcohol withdrawal seizures, the initial treatment of choice is typically a benzodiazepine such as diazepam. Benzodiazepines are effective in rapidly controlling seizures and managing the symptoms of alcohol withdrawal.

 

Treatment for Alcohol withdrawal symptoms –

 

  • Diazepam (40–80 mg/day in divided doses) is used.
  • Oral multi-B vitamins, including thiamine 50–100 mg is given daily for a week or more.
  • Chlordiazepoxide (80–200 mg/day in divided doses) or haloperidol 20 mg or more/day may be used.
  • Intravenous fluids are avoided, unless there is evidence of bleeding, vomiting or diarrhea.
  • In cases of urgent sedation as in delirium tremens— phenobarbitone or chlorpromazine injection can be given, and then detoxification and maintenance of nutrition is carried on with 5% dextrose solution IV and thiamine.
  • Symptomatic treatment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Phenobarbital: While phenobarbital can be used for seizures, it is not typically the initial choice for alcohol withdrawal seizures.
 

Option C. Disulfiram: Disulfiram is used in the management of alcohol dependence but is not indicated for acute seizure treatment.
 

Option D. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) is essential in the management of Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome associated with chronic alcohol use, but it is not the initial treatment for alcohol withdrawal seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benzodiazepines like diazepam are the initial treatment of choice for alcohol withdrawal seizures.  (40–80 mg/day in divided doses)

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 580

choices.text: Alteration in mental function
VI th nerve palsy

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with a constellation of neurological symptoms, including alteration in mental function, VIth nerve palsy, and ataxia. These symptoms are concerning Wernicke's encephalopathy. Which of the following symptoms is NOT typically associated with Wernicke's encephalopathy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cogwheel rigidity

 

Explanation:

 

Wernicke’s Encephalopathy - This is an acute reaction due to severe thiamine deficiency (Vit. B1), the commonest cause being chronic alcohol abuse. Characteristically, the onset occurs after a period of persistent vomiting.

 

Signs and Symptom

 

  1. Ocular: Coarse nystagmus and opthalmoparesis (usually the VIth cranial nerve is involved). Pupillary irregularity, retinal hemorrhages, papilledema and impairment of vision.
  2. CNS: Disorientation, confusion, recent memory disturbances, poor attention span and distractibility. Apathy and ataxia are early symptoms.
  3. Peripheral neuropath  and serious malnutrition are often coexistent.
  4. Pathologically, neuronal degeneration and hemorrhage is seen in the thalamus, hypothalamus (mammillary bodies) and midbrain.

 

Cogwheel rigidity may be seen in associated with other extrapyramidal manifestation of Organophosphorus poisoning. It develops in 4–40 days following poisoning and lasts for about 1-4 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke's encephalopathy is characterized by a triad of symptoms, including alteration in mental function (confusion), ophthalmoplegia (paralysis of eye muscles), and ataxia (loss of muscle coordination). VIth nerve palsy (involvement of the sixth cranial nerve) can result in difficulty moving the eyes laterally, leading to double vision and cogwheel rigidity is not a characteristic feature.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 580

choices.text: Disorientation in time and place

questions.text: In a psychiatric evaluation at a rehabilitation center, a medical officer is assessing a patient with a history of chronic alcohol abuse. The patient exhibits certain neuropsychiatric symptoms that are suggestive of a specific syndrome related to alcohol-related brain damage. Based on the clinical presentation, the medical officer is considering the diagnosis of Korsakoff's psychosis. Which of the following clinical findings is most strongly indicative of Korsakoff's psychosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Confabulation

 

Option C:

 

Confabulation is the most strongly indicative clinical finding of Korsakoff's psychosis. It refers to the phenomenon where the patient fabricates events to fill in memory gaps, often unaware that these events are not real. This symptom is particularly characteristic of Korsakoff's psychosis, which is a late neuropsychiatric manifestation of Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, often related to chronic alcohol abuse and thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Visual hallucinations: Not as specifically indicative of Korsakoff's psychosis as confabulation.

 

Option B. Disorientation in time and place: This can be a symptom of various cognitive disorders, including dementia and delirium, but is not as specific for Korsakoff's psychosis as confabulation.

 

Option D. Aggressive behavior: Not specifically indicative of Korsakoff's psychosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In evaluating patients with a history of chronic alcoholism, the presence of confabulation is a key clinical indicator of Korsakoff's psychosis. Recognizing this symptom is important for medical officers, as it aids in the differential diagnosis of neuropsychiatric disorders and guides appropriate treatment and management strategies.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 580

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. His friend reports that he has been a chronic alcoholic for many years. On examination, he has impaired short-term memory and disorientation. Which area of the brain is usually spared from involvement in his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hippocampus

 

Option C:

 

Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome - It presents as an organic amnestic syndrome, characterized by inability to learn new information, impairment of short-term memory and compensatory confabulation. Insight is often impaired. The pathological lesion is usually widespread, but changes are seen in bilateral dorsomedial nuclei of thalamus and mammillary bodies. The changes are also seen in periventricular and periaqueductal gray matter, cerebellum and parts of brainstem.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Periventricular gray matter: This area is commonly involved in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Option B. Mammillary bodies: These are typically affected in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Option D. Thalamus: The thalamus, particularly the medial thalamic region, is frequently involved in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, contributing to various neuropsychiatric symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, a neuropsychiatric condition associated with thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, often seen in chronic alcoholics. In this condition, the hippocampus is typically spared from involvement, while other areas like the mammillary bodies and periventricular gray matter are affected, leading to the characteristic symptoms.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 580

choices.text: Wrist and foot drop

questions.text: During a seminar focused on the psychiatric and neurological impacts of chronic alcohol abuse, a discussion is centered around alcohol paranoia, a specific psychiatric condition. To gauge the students' understanding of this condition, a question is posed regarding its characteristic features. Which of the following statements accurately describes a key feature of alcohol paranoia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fixed delusions

 

Option C:

 

The patient's presentation is consistent with alcohol paranoia, a condition characterized by the development of fixed delusions. These delusions are often persecutory in nature and lead to paranoid thoughts and behaviors. Fixed delusions are a hallmark of alcohol paranoia, distinguishing it from transient hallucinations or delirium.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tremors: Tremors are common in alcohol withdrawal but are not specific to alcohol paranoia.

 

Option B. Hallucinations: While hallucinations can occur in alcohol withdrawal, the fixed and persecutory nature of delusions is more characteristic of alcohol paranoia.

 

Option D. Wrist and foot drop: This symptom is typically associated with alcoholic peripheral neuropathy. Other Symptoms of alcoholic polyneuritis are weakness, pain in extremities, unsteady gait, loss of deep reflexes and tenderness of muscles of arms and legs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcoholic paranoia: In this, there is a fixed delusion, but no hallucinations. Patient becomes suspicious of the motives and actions of those he meets and of his family members.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 580

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency room in an intoxicated state. He had consumed a significant amount of alcohol at a party. The medical team needs to estimate his blood alcohol level for medical and legal purposes. Which of the following methods is considered the most reliable for estimating blood alcohol level?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gas liquid chromatography

 

Option C:


Gas liquid chromatography is the most reliable method for estimating blood alcohol levels. It provides accurate and quantitative measurements of alcohol concentration in the blood and is widely used in forensic and medical settings for assessing intoxication levels.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cavett’s test (Kozelka and Hine method): This is an older chemical method, a less reliable one, for estimating blood alcohol levels. It involves aeration/distillation or diffusion of alcohol under low pressure. It utilizes the principle that alcohol is easily oxidized to acetic acid by oxidizing agents, such as potassium dichromate and sulfuric acid.

 

Option B. Breath alcohol analyzer: While breath analyzers are commonly used for field sobriety testing due to its convenience, preliminary testing, it uses infrared spectroscopy to determine alcohol concentration.

 

Option D. Thin layer chromatography: Thin layer chromatography is not typically used for blood alcohol level estimation. Fresh and dried seminal stains can be identified by a thin layer chromatographic technique due to the combination of choline and spermine which is present only in semen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gas liquid chromatography (GLC): Most reliable method for estimating blood alcohol levels. It is extremely sensitive and produces accurate quantitative results.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 497

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after being stopped at a roadside sobriety checkpoint. The police suspect alcohol intoxication due to his slurred speech and unsteady gait. The emergency medical team decides to use a breathalyzer test to assess his blood alcohol concentration. For educational purposes, the attending physician asks the medical residents to identify the chemical used in the breathalyzer test for both qualitative and quantitative assessment of alcohol in expired air.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Potassium dichromate

 

Option D:

 

Potassium dichromate is commonly used in breath alcohol analyzers to assess alcohol levels in the expired air. It reacts with alcohol in the breath, producing color changes that are quantitatively analyzed to determine the alcohol concentration.

 

Note - Recently developed Breath analyzers rely on infrared absorption of energy by ethyl alcohol vapor in breath samples.

 

Kozelka and Hine method or Cavett method: It involves aeration/distillation or diffusion of alcohol under low pressure. It utilizes the principle that alcohol is easily oxidized to acetic acid by oxidizing agents, such as potassium dichromate and sulfuric acid.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aniline: Aniline is not used in breathalyzer tests; it's a chemical used in the manufacture of dyes, plastics, and pharmaceuticals.

 

Option B. Diphenylamine: Diphenylamine is used in various chemical processes but not for detecting alcohol in expired air.

 

Option C. Potassium ferrocyanide: This chemical is not used in breathalyzer tests. It has various industrial applications, including as an anti-caking agent in salt.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Potassium dichromate is the chemical commonly used for assessing alcohol levels in the expired air during breath alcohol testing.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 577

choices.text: Treatment is with ethanol
Toxicity is due to methanol

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is brought to the emergency department. He reports attending a social gathering the previous night where he consumed homemade liquor. His vital signs show a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg, and a heart rate of 110 bpm. The medical team suspects contaminated liquor poisoning. Considering the clinical and laboratory findings, which of the following statements is NOT true about this case of suspected contaminated liquor poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metabolic alkalosis

 

Option A:

 

In this scenario, the patient's symptoms and laboratory findings are indicative of methanol poisoning, often associated with the consumption of contaminated homemade liquor.

 

Methanol poisoning typically leads to a high anion gap metabolic acidosis, not alkalosis, due to the production of formic acid upon metabolism.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Blindness: Methanol toxicity can cause optic nerve damage leading to blurred vision or blindness, consistent with the patient's symptoms.

 

Option C. Treatment is with ethanol: Ethanol is used as an antidote in methanol poisoning. It competes with methanol for metabolism, thereby reducing the formation of toxic metabolites.

 

Option D. Toxicity is due to methanol: The clinical presentation is suggestive of methanol poisoning, a common risk with homemade or contaminated liquor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected contaminated liquor poisoning, it's important to recognize the signs of methanol toxicity, which typically presents with metabolic acidosis and potential for optic nerve damage. Ethanol is used as an antidote in the treatment of methanol poisoning. Understanding these clinical presentations and appropriate treatments is crucial in emergency medicine.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 582-583

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to a district hospital in India with symptoms of delirium, dilated pupils, dry mouth, and tachycardia. He was found in a confused state near a garden known to have Datura plants. The attending medical officer suspects Datura poisoning. Which of the following compounds is NOT typically found in Datura, a plant known for its belladonna alkaloids and suspected in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Muscarine

 

Option C:

 

Datura contains belladonna alkaloids, which have primary anticholinergic actions. The primary alkaloids in Datura are hyoscine (scopolamine), hyoscyamine, and atropine. These substances block the acetylcholine receptor, producing sympathomimetic or parasympatholytic actions. In the early phase, they act as CNS stimulants, but later they can cause CNS depression, particularly of the respiratory center, and have a vagolytic action resulting in heart stimulation.

 

Muscarine, on the other hand, is not typically found in Datura. It is associated with certain mushroom poisonings and has a distinct mechanism of action, primarily affecting muscarinic acetylcholine receptors.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hyoscine (Scopolamine): Incorrect because it is one of the active components of Datura, contributing to its anticholinergic effects.

 

Option B. Hyoscyamine: Incorrect as it is also present in Datura and contributes to the plant's overall anticholinergic profile.

 

Option D. Atropine: Incorrect because it is a constituent of Datura and is known for its anticholinergic effects, including dilated pupils and tachycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Datura primarily contains tropane alkaloids like hyoscine, hyoscyamine, and atropine, which cause anticholinergic symptoms. Muscarine, although a toxic compound, is not found in Datura and is more commonly associated with mushroom poisoning, affecting muscarinic acetylcholine receptors.

 

Remember - 9 D's: Dryness of mouth, dysphagia, dysarthria, dilated pupils (diplopia, mydriasis), dry hot skin, dilatation of cutaneous blood vessels, drunken gait, delirium, drowsiness.

 

Additionally, diminished bowel movements, distention of urinary bladder, Increased respiration, Scarlatiniform rash over the body, Amnesia and death due to respiratory failure.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 598

questions.text: A medical officer in a rural health clinic is confronted with a case of suspected plant poisoning. The patient, a young adult, presents with various symptoms after reportedly consuming a local plant. The officer is aware of the "9 Ds" commonly associated with Datura intoxication and assesses the patient for these symptoms. Which of the following symptoms is not typically included in the "9 Ds" of Datura intoxication, and therefore might suggest a different diagnosis or an additional complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diarrhea

 

Option A:

 

The "9 Ds" of Datura intoxication usually include symptoms such as Dryness of mouth, dysphagia, dysarthria, dilated pupils (diplopia, mydriasis), dry hot skin, dilatation of cutaneous blood vessels, drunken gait, delirium, drowsiness. Thus, Diarrhea is not typically a symptom of Datura intoxication due to its anticholinergic effects, which are more likely to cause constipation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Dysphagia: Dysphagia or difficulty in swallowing can occur due to the dry mucous membranes caused by the anticholinergic effects of Datura.

 

Option C. Drowsiness: Drowsiness or sedation can be a part of the anticholinergic syndrome caused by Datura intoxication.

 

Option D. Dilated pupil: Dilated pupils, or mydriasis, are a characteristic feature of Datura intoxication due to the blockade of the muscarinic acetylcholine receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remember - 9 D's: Dryness of mouth, dysphagia, dysarthria, dilated pupils (diplopia, mydriasis), dry hot skin, dilatation of cutaneous blood vessels, drunken gait, delirium and drowsiness. Additionally, diminished bowel movements, distention of urinary bladder, Increased respiration, Scarlatiniform rash over the body, Amnesia and death due to respiratory failure.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 599

questions.text: In the emergency department, a patient is admitted with symptoms suggestive of an acute drug overdose. The patient is unresponsive with shallow breathing, hypotension, and bradycardia. Laboratory reports confirm the presence of barbiturates. The medical team discusses the treatment protocol, focusing on both supportive care and specific interventions to enhance drug elimination. What is the appropriate method to enhance drug elimination in this case of barbiturate poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urine alkalization

 

Option A:

 

In the management of barbiturate poisoning, urine alkalization is a key method for enhancing drug elimination. This is achieved through forced alkaline diuresis using sodium bicarbonate. Alkalizing the urine increases the ionization of barbiturates, reducing their reabsorption in the renal tubules and thereby enhancing their excretion. This method is a part of the comprehensive management that includes airway support, cardiovascular support, decontamination (like gastric lavage and activated charcoal), and in some cases, extracorporeal drug removal methods such as hemodialysis or hemoperfusion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hemodialysis: Hemodialysis or hemoperfusion can be indicated in severe cases, especially for phenobarbital poisoning.

 

Option C. Activated charcoal: Used for gastrointestinal decontamination but does not enhance elimination in the kidneys.

 

Option D. Gastric lavage: Gastric lavage can be used in early presentation of poisoning but is not a method for enhancing drug elimination in the kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In barbiturate poisoning, management includes supportive care and specific interventions to enhance drug elimination. Urine alkalization via forced alkaline diuresis is an effective method for enhancing the renal excretion of barbiturates. Understanding these treatment modalities is crucial in emergency medicine for managing drug overdoses effectively.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 589

questions.text: In the emergency department of a district hospital, a medical officer encounters a case of suspected Datura poisoning. The patient presents with symptoms consistent with anticholinergic toxicity, including confusion, dry mouth, and dilated pupils. The medical officer considers the treatment options for counteracting the effects of Datura. Which medication is most appropriate for the treatment of Datura poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Physostigmine

 

Option C:

 

Physostigmine is the treatment of choice for Datura poisoning. It is a cholinesterase inhibitor that crosses the blood-brain barrier and can reverse the central and peripheral anticholinergic effects of Datura. Physostigmine increases the level of acetylcholine at synapses, thereby countering the anticholinergic symptoms induced by Datura.

 

Treatment –

 

  • Emetics.
  • Gastric lavage with tannic acid, KMnO4 or activated charcoal. First dose of activated charcoal may be given with cathartic (e.g. sorbitol). One or two additional doses may be given at 1–2 h intervals to ensure adequate gut decontamination.
  • Physiological antidote: Physostigmine salicylate - 0.5–1 mg slow IV over 5 min with ECG monitoring (0.02 mg/kg/dose).
  • Pilocarpine 5–15 mg subcutaneously is also useful.
  • Purgatives and colonic lavage is recommended.
  • Tepid sponge baths to control high temperature, and diazepam IV for sedation and seizures. Morphine is avoided.
  • Delirium is controlled by short acting barbiturates.
  • O2 inhalation and artificial respiration.
  • Hemodialysis and hemoperfusion are generally ineffective (tropane alkaloids are lipophilic and cross the blood-brain barrier).
  • Catheterization in case of urinary retention.
  • Moistening of the tongue and change in the size of pupils point towards normalization and are useful as guidelines for adequate management.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pilocarpine: Pilocarpine is a direct muscarinic agonist; it can be given but not the antidote of Datura poisoning. In usual doses is a physiological antidote in Thallium poisoning.

 

Option B. Naloxone: Naloxone is an opioid antagonist and is effective against Opium poisoning.

 

Option D. Neostigmine: Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor but does not cross the blood-brain barrier, making it less effective for central anticholinergic symptoms compared to physostigmine. It is used for muscarinic symptoms seen in cobra envenomation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of Datura poisoning, physostigmine is the preferred treatment due to its to cross the blood-brain barrier and reverse both central and peripheral anticholinergic effects.

 

Additional Information

 

Clinical toxidromes -

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 598 -599

questions.text: In a rural health clinic, Ramesh, a 40-year-old male, presents with symptoms of bronchodilation, increased body temperature, constipation, and tachycardia. The medical officer, after conducting a preliminary examination, considers these symptoms in the context of potential poisoning cases. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most probable diagnosis for Ramesh's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atropine

 

Option B:

 

The symptoms presented by Ramesh - bronchodilation, increased body temperature (hyperthermia), constipation, and tachycardia - are indicative of anticholinergic syndrome, which is typically caused by substances like atropine. Atropine is an anticholinergic agent that can cause these symptoms by inhibiting the action of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine in the body.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mushroom: Certain mushrooms, particularly those containing muscarine, cause cholinergic syndrome, which presents with symptoms opposite to those of anticholinergic syndrome (e.g., bronchoconstriction, bradycardia).

 

Option C. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning typically presents with gastrointestinal distress, cardiac issues, and neuropathy, not the anticholinergic symptoms seen here.

 

Option D. Organophosphorus: Organophosphorus compounds cause cholinergic syndrome due to acetylcholinesterase inhibition, leading to symptoms like salivation, lacrimation, urination, diarrhea, gastrointestinal distress, and emesis (SLUDGE syndrome), which differ from Ramesh's presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the clinical presentation of anticholinergic syndrome is essential in diagnosing atropine or similar anticholinergic poisoning. These agents cause a distinctive symptom profile that includes bronchodilation, increased body temperature, constipation, and tachycardia, aiding medical officers in identifying and managing such poisoning cases effectively.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 600

questions.text: During the investigation of a sudden death case, a forensic expert examines the belongings of the deceased. Among the items, various substances are found, and the expert is tasked with identifying them to understand the potential cause of death. Which of the following substances found at the scene is NOT a form of cannabis and might suggest a different toxicological pathway in the autopsy findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Afeem

 

Option C:

 

Afeem, which is not a form of cannabis but rather the Hindi term for opium, points to a different toxicological cause. Opium, derived from the opium poppy (Papaver somniferum), contains alkaloids such as morphine and codeine, which are opioids.

 

While the active Principle of cannabis is not an alkaloid, but a fat-soluble oleoresin, cannabinol, the active form being δ-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC). It also contains benzopyrene, a known carcinogen which is also found in tobacco.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bhang: Incorrect. Bhang is a form of cannabis made from the leaves and flowers of the cannabis plant and is commonly used in some cultural practices in India.

 

Option B. Charas: Incorrect. Charas is a form of cannabis, a resin extracted from the cannabis plant, often used for its psychoactive effects.

 

Option D. Ganja: Incorrect. Ganja refers to the dried flower buds of the cannabis plant and is a well-known form of cannabis used recreationally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It emphasizes the importance of recognizing that afeem (opium) is not a form of cannabis but a distinct substance with different active components and toxicological effects. The question aids in understanding that while cannabis contains δ-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and is known for its psychoactive properties, opium contains opioids like morphine and codeine, which have different pharmacological and toxicological profiles.

 

Additional Information -

 

Various preparations of Cannabis -

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 600

questions.text: A patient with a history of substance addiction is brought to the emergency department presenting with visual and tactile hallucinations. The medical team also observed black staining on the patient's tongue and teeth. Based on these clinical signs, the medical officer considers the possible substances involved. Which agent is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cocaine

 

Option A:

 

The combination of visual and tactile hallucinations, along with the characteristic black staining of the tongue and teeth, suggests cocaine as the likely substance. Cocaine use can cause a variety of neurological and psychological effects, including hallucinations. The black staining is a distinctive feature associated with the smoking of crack cocaine.

 

 

Black staining of teeth and tongue

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Cannabis: Incorrect. While cannabis can cause hallucinations, it is not typically associated with black staining of the tongue and teeth.

 

Option C. Heroin: Incorrect. Heroin does not typically cause hallucinations or black staining of the tongue and teeth.

 

Option D. Opium: Incorrect. Opium does not typically lead to hallucinations or black dental staining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Cocaine Poisoning (COCAINISM/ COCAINOPHAGIA/COCAINOMANIA)

 

  1. The victim presents with an unstable mental condition or psychopathic tendency, which presents with manifestation, such as:
    1. Toxic delirium
    2. Psychotic disorder characterized by paranoid delusions, visual and tactile hallucination.
    3. Tactile hallucinations are characteristic. This is also called cocaine bugs/ Formication/ Magnan symptom.
  2. Sexual and reproductive dysfunction
  3. Crack Babies: Cocaine abuse by pregnant women has been associated with an increased risk of congenital malformations in the foetus called crack babies.
  4. Tongue and teeth becomes black

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 603

questions.text: In the emergency department, a person is brought in exhibiting signs of severe itching and the sensation of small insects creeping on the skin. The medical officer, recognizing these symptoms, considers the likely cause of this presentation. Which condition is most commonly associated with these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cocaine poisoning

 

Option A:

 

The sensation of insects creeping on the skin, known as formication, along with severe itching, is commonly associated with cocaine poisoning. This is a hallucinatory sensation typical of stimulant intoxication, particularly with cocaine.

 

Formication: Tactile hallucination involving the sensation that tiny insects are crawling over the skin. The causes of formication can be actual physical conditions, including diabetic neuropathy, menopause, skin cancer or herpes zoster, and may also be physical or psychological side effect of substance abuse (cocaine, amphetamines, and alcohol withdrawal along with delirium tremens).

 

Explanation:
