Option B. OPC (Organophosphorus compounds): Incorrect. OPC poisoning typically presents with symptoms related to cholinergic excess but not Magnan's syndrome.

 

Option C. Snake bite: Incorrect. Not associated with Magnan's syndrome.

 

Option D. Alcohol: Incorrect. Alcohol withdrawal or intoxication can cause various psychiatric symptoms, but Magnan's syndrome is not among them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Magnan's Syndrome / Cocaine Bugs - This is seen in cocaine addicts, a type of tactile hallucination. There is a feeling as if grains of sand are lying under the skin or small insects are creeping on the skin giving rise to itching sensation (formication).

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 603

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by the police after being found in a disoriented state at a railway platform. He exhibits symptoms of confusion, dry mouth, hot dry skin, dilated pupils, staggering gait, and slurred speech. The clinical team suspects a case of poisoning and considers various possibilities based on the presenting symptoms. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Datura poisoning

 

Option B:

 

The patient's symptoms are indicative of anticholinergic syndrome, which aligns with Datura poisoning. Datura contains compounds like atropine and hyoscyamine that lead to symptoms such as dilated pupils, dry mouth and skin, confusion, and motor incoordination. These symptoms differentiate Datura poisoning from other causes such as alcohol intoxication, OPC poisoning, or aconite poisoning.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alcoholic intoxication: While it can lead to confusion and motor incoordination, the other anticholinergic symptoms like dry mouth and dilated pupils are not typical.

 

Option C. OPC poisoning: Characterized by cholinergic symptoms, not anticholinergic effects.

 

Option D. Aconite poisoning: Typically presents with cardiovascular symptoms, not the anticholinergic syndrome seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remember - 9 D's: Dryness of mouth, dysphagia, dysarthria, dilated pupils (diplopia, mydriasis), dry hot skin, dilatation of cutaneous blood vessels, drunken gait, delirium and drowsiness. Additionally, diminished bowel movements, distention of urinary bladder, Increased respiration, Scarlatiniform rash over the body, Amnesia and death due to respiratory failure.

 

Additional Information –

 

Treatment of Dhatura Poisoning –

 

  • Emetics.
  • Gastric lavage with tannic acid, KMnO4 or activated charcoal. First dose of activated charcoal may be given with cathartic (e.g. sorbitol). One or two additional doses may be given at 1–2 h intervals to ensure adequate gut decontamination.
  • Physiological antidote: Physostigmine salicylate (reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor capable of directly antagonizing CNS manifestations of anticholinergic toxicity) 0.5–1 mg slow IV over 5 min with ECG monitoring (0.02 mg/kg/dose).
  • Pilocarpine 5–15 mg subcutaneously is also useful.
  • Purgatives and colonic lavage is recommended.
  • Tepid sponge baths to control high temperature, and diazepam IV for sedation and seizures. Morphine is avoided.
  • Delirium is controlled by short acting barbiturates.
  • O2 inhalation and artificial respiration.
  • Hemodialysis and hemoperfusion are generally ineffective (tropane alkaloids are lipophilic and cross the blood-brain barrier).
  • Catheterization in case of urinary retention.
  • Moistening of the tongue and change in the size of pupils point towards normalization and are useful as guidelines for adequate management.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 598 -599

questions.text: In a forensic investigation involving various cannabis products, the forensic expert at a medical college in India needs to determine which substance found at a crime scene represents the most potent form of cannabis. This determination is crucial to understand the potential impact on the individuals involved in the case. Identify which of the following is considered the most potent form of cannabis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hash oil

 

Option D:

 

Hash oil is the most potent form of cannabis. It is a concentrated resin extract derived from cannabis, and it contains a higher concentration of the psychoactive compound THC (tetrahydrocannabinol) compared to other forms like bhang, charas, and ganja. The high concentration of THC in hash oil results in increased potency.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bhang: Incorrect. Bhang is the mildest (15% THC) form of cannabis, made from dried cannabis leaves mixed with sugar, spices, and fruit.

 

Option B. Charas: Incorrect. Charas is a form of hashish, potent but not as concentrated in THC as hash oil. It has 25-40% THC.

 

Option C. Ganja: Incorrect. Ganja consists of dried leaves and flowers of the cannabis plant and, while psychoactive, is less potent (15-25% THC) compared to hash oil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While bhang, charas, and ganja are common forms of cannabis, hash oil stands out as the most potent due to its high (25-50%) THC concentration.

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 600

choices.text: Running away from a stressful situation
Feeling of insects running under skin
Ingesting corrosive substances in rage

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the term “run-amok”?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Killing people randomly.

 

Option B:

 

"Run-amok" refers to a sudden outburst of aggressive and violent behavior, historically characterized by indiscriminate attacking or killing of people around the individual. It is an abrupt episode of unrestrained and aggressive behavior, often with lethal outcomes, that seems to lack a clear motive or target. This is characterized by a peculiar homicidal mania.

 

He first kills a person against whom he may have real or imaginary enemity and then kills anyone that comes in his way until the homicidal tendency lasts. Then he may commit suicide or may surrender himself.

 

Criminal responsibility: The person is not held responsible for his acts since ‘run amok’ is considered a disorder of mind and not intoxication, unless he had taken it purposefully to ennerve (strengthen) himself before commission of the offence.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Running away from a stressful situation: This does not match the violent nature of "run-amok."

 

Option C. Feeling of insects running under skin: This is more indicative of a tactile hallucination, unrelated to "run-amok."

 

Option D. Ingesting corrosive substances in rage: While this could indicate self-harm or extreme behavior in rage, it does not correspond to the traditional definition of "run-amok."

 

Educational Objective:

 

Run Amok is a characteristic feature seen in psychosis caused in chronic cannabis poisoning

Characteristic features of Cannabis:

 

  1. Amotivational Syndrome: There is apathy, poor concentration, social withdrawal, and lack of motivation to study or work.
  2. Cannabis Psychosis (Hashish Psychosis): Increased tendency to develop manic, schizophreniform, and confusional psychoses over a period of time. Run Amok is also seen. In Run amok the person will kill first his enemy and then everyone else on his way and finally commits suicide.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 601

questions.text: In a case of suspected poisoning being investigated by a forensic expert, the evidence points towards the use of a specific toxic agent. Based on the symptoms observed and the substances found at the scene, the expert is considering strychnine poisoning. Strychnine acts by inhibiting which of the following neurotransmitters?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycine

 

Option B:

 

Strychnine competitively antagonizes the inhibitory neurotransmitter glycine by blocking its post-synaptic uptake by brainstem and spinal cord receptors.

 

The inhibiting effect of glycine is reduced, and nerve impulses are triggered with lower levels of neurotransmitters.

 

When there is no inhibitory effect, the motor neurons do not stop their stimulus, and the victim will have constant muscle contractions ('release excitation'). Its action is particularly in the anterior horn cells (especially in Renshaw cells of the spinal cord).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. GABA: Incorrect. GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) the neurotransmitter for presynaptic inhibitory neurons is not affected by strychnine

 

Option C. Acetylcholine: Incorrect. Acetylcholine is a neurotransmitter involved in muscle activation and various other functions, but it is not the primary target of strychnine.

 

Option D. Dopamine: Incorrect. Dopamine is a neurotransmitter associated with reward and motor control, among other functions, but is not inhibited by strychnine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strychnine poisoning, characterized by the inhibition of glycine, leads to pronounced muscle spasms and convulsions, which are important clues in autopsy findings

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 612-613

questions.text: During a postmortem examination at a medical college, a forensic expert encounters a case where the deceased is suspected to have been poisoned with nux vomica. A notable feature observed during the examination is the posture of the spine. The forensic expert is considering which posture is commonly assumed by the spine in cases of nux vomica poisoning. In nux vomica poisoning, the posture commonly assumed by the spine is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Opisthotonus

 

Option A:

 

Nux vomica poisoning, which typically involves strychnine, causes severe muscle spasms due to its action as a glycine antagonist. The most characteristic posture assumed due to these spasms is opisthotonus. Opisthotonus is a condition in which the body is in a hyperextended position, with the spine and head arched backward, a result of severe muscle contractions.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Emprosthotonus: Incorrect. Emprosthotonus involves forward bending of the body, which is not characteristic of nux vomica poisoning.

 

Option C. Pleurosthotonus: Incorrect. Pleurosthotonus involves sideways bending of the body, which is not typically seen in nux vomica poisoning.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Neither emprosthotonus nor pleurosthotonus is typically associated with nux vomica poisoning.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 612-613

questions.text: In a recent case of suspected strychnine poisoning at a district hospital, the attending medical officer is preparing to administer the appropriate antidote. Given the severe muscle spasms and convulsions caused by strychnine, a neurotoxin that inhibits glycine, the medical officer must choose the correct antidote to manage these symptoms effectively. What is the appropriate antidote for strychnine poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Barbiturates

 

Option C:

 

Barbiturates are used as an antidote for strychnine poisoning. It works by providing central nervous system depression and reducing muscle spasms and convulsions, which are characteristic of strychnine toxicity. Barbiturates help to control the overstimulation caused by the inhibition of inhibitory neurotransmitters by strychnine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fomepizole: Incorrect. Fomepizole is an antidote for methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning, not for strychnine.

 

Option B. Physostigmine: Incorrect. Physostigmine is used for anticholinergic toxicity (Dhatura poisoning).

 

Option D. Naloxone: Incorrect. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist and is effective against opium poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barbiturates are used as an antidote for strychnine poisoning.

 

Additional Information –

 

Treatment of Strychnine Poisoning –

 

Treatment involves supportive care with minimization of external stimulus and prevention of convulsions.

 

  • Maintain clear airway and adequate ventilation including endotracheal intubation.
  • Control of convulsions: Dark room, free from noise and disturbance. Diazepam 0.1–0.5 mg/kg IV slowly. If ineffective, general anesthetics and/or muscle relaxants, like gallamine should be given.
  • Barbiturates, like pentobarbital sodium or sodium amytal are antidotes. Dose: 300–600 mg IV.
  • Gastric lavage with KMnO4 may be done cautiously, if there are no convulsions. Activated charcoal is recommended as it adsorbs strychnine and may reduce its absorption if given 1 hr of ingestion.
  • Hyperthermia is treated by active cooling with ice water immersion, cooling blanket or mist and fan.
  • Intravenous fluid is given to maintain a urine output > 1 ml/kg/hr, since metabolic acidosis and renal failure may occur. (Hemodialysis is not effective).
  • Symptomatic treatment.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 613

choices.text: Tingling and numbness

questions.text: A patient is brought to a rural health center with symptoms that suggest possible plant-based poisoning. Considering the local flora and the potential for accidental ingestion of toxic plants, the medical officer assesses the symptoms for a specific diagnosis. Which of the following is a characteristic symptom of aconite poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tingling and numbness

 

Option C:

 

Aconite poisoning is characterized by a distinct combination of gastrointestinal, cardiovascular, and neurological symptoms. The most indicative among these, based on the provided information, is the sensation of tingling and numbness, particularly in the tongue, mouth, perioral area, and throat. This symptom is a direct result of aconite's neurotoxic effects and often precedes more severe systemic manifestations, such as hypotension, bradycardia, or ventricular arrhythmias, making it a critical indicator for forensic investigation in cases of suspected poisoning.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increased salivation: Incorrect. While salivation is a symptom of aconite poisoning, it is not as specific or early an indicator as tingling and numbness.

 

Option B. Hypertension: Incorrect. Aconite poisoning more commonly leads to hypotension, not hypertension.

 

Option D. Hyperthermia: Incorrect. Aconite poisoning is associated with subnormal temperature, not hyperthermia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tingling and Numbness are characteristic symptoms of aconite poisoning.

 

Additional Information:

 

key symptoms of aconite poisoning –

 

  • GIT - Nausea, vomiting, salivation, pain in the abdomen and diarrhea. Bitter-sweet taste, severe burning and tingling of tongue, mouth, perioral area and throat, followed by numbness.
  • CVS - Hypotension, chest pain, palpitations, bradycardia, sinus tachycardia, ventricular ectopics and ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation. Pulse is slow, feeble and irregular.
  • CNS - Vertigo, restlessness, headache, giddiness.
  • MS - Weakness of the muscles of the limbs with twitchings and spasms.
  • RS - Respiration is slow, labored and shallow.
  • Ocular - Pupils alternately contract and dilate (hippus). Diplopia and impaired vision occurs.
  • Others Temperature is subnormal and skin is cold.

 

Terminal stages are marked by severe pain and paralysis of facial muscles. Many victims remain conscious until near death; some complain of yellow-green vision and tinnitus. Death is due to respiratory failure or ventricular fibrillation.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 619

questions.text: In a forensic session, the faculty discusses the toxicology of various plants. One of the plants under discussion is the oleander, known for its toxic properties. The faculty asks the students to identify the active principle (the main toxic compound) found in the oleander plant. Which compound is the active principle of the oleander plant?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nerin

 

Option D:

 

Nerin is the primary active principle of the oleander plant. The oleander contains toxic compounds, specifically three glycosides named neriodorin, neriodorein, and karabin, all of which contribute to the overall toxicity of nerin.

 

Action - It is similar to that of digitalis causing death from cardiac failure. Neriodorein causes muscular twitching and tetanic spasm which is more powerful than strychnine. Karabin acts on the heart like digitalis, and on the spinal cord like strychnine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cannabinol: Incorrect. Cannabinol is associated with cannabis, not oleander.

 

Option B. Atropine: Incorrect. Atropine is found in plants like belladonna and datura, not in oleander.

 

Option C. Semicarpol: Incorrect. Semicarpol is not a known active principle of the oleander plant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Some important pointers related to oleander -

 

  • Nerium Odorum (White Oleander, Kaner) - All parts of the plant are poisonous. Active principles: Nerin consisting of three glycosides— neriodorin, neriodorein and karabin. It is similar to that of digitalis causing death from cardiac failure.
  • Cerbera Thevetia (Yellow Oleander, Pila Kaner) - All parts of the plant are poisonous. Milky juice exudes from all parts of the plant. Active principles: Glycosides—thevetin, thevotoxin, cerberin and peruvoside. Thevetin is a powerful cardiac poison. Thevotoxin is less toxic than thevetin and resembles the glycosides of digitalis in action. Cerberin acts like strychnine.
  • Medicolegal aspects of Oleander - Suicide is common among village girls, using it as a paste or decoction, It is used as an abortifacient, applied both locally and internally. Also used as cattle poison. Nerium odorum resists heat and can therefore be detected even from the burnt remains of the dead body.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 616

questions.text: During a forensic investigation training session, the topic of cyanide poisoning is discussed. One of the instructors, a forensic expert explains how certain sensory clues can aid in the initial assessment of a poisoning case. The officer then asks the trainees about the characteristic odor associated with cyanide to test their knowledge of toxic substances. What is the odor of cyanide?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bitter almond

 

Option D:

 

Cyanide is often described as having a bitter almond odor. This distinctive smell can be a crucial clue in identifying cyanide poisoning during a forensic investigation. However, it's important to note that not everyone can detect this odor due to a genetic trait.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rotten egg: Incorrect. The smell of rotten eggs is typically associated with hydrogen sulfide, Mercaptans, Disulfirum.

 

Option B. Fishy: Incorrect. A fishy odor is characteristic of Zinc Phosphide, Aluminum Phosphide Poisoning.

 

Option C. Fruity: Incorrect. Chemicals like Ethanol, Methyl or Propyl Alcohol, Chloroform, Nitrites, Acetone have a fruity odor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Smell due to various poisons

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 627

questions.text: During a toxicology seminar, a junior resident is presenting a challenging case of cyanide poisoning. The presentation aims to elucidate the mechanism of action of cyanide, as understanding this is critical in both forensic investigations and clinical management. How does cyanide cause its toxic effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cytochrome oxidase

 

Option B:

 

Cyanide inhibits the action of cytochrome oxidase, carbonic anhydrase and probably of other enzyme systems. It blocks the final step of oxidative phosphorylation and prevents the formation of ATP and its use as energy source.

 

As a result, aerobic metabolism is arrested, leading to histotoxic anoxia. The body's shift to increased anaerobic glycolysis in response to this blockage leads to lactic acid production and potential severe acid-base imbalance.

 

Additionally, cyanide also acts as a corrosive on mucosal surfaces.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. DNA synthesis: Incorrect. Cyanide's toxic effect is not primarily on DNA synthesis.

 

Option C. Protein breakdown: Incorrect. Cyanide's main toxic effect does not involve protein breakdown.

 

Option D. Protein synthesis: Incorrect. The inhibition of protein synthesis is not the primary mechanism of cyanide toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HCN is a protoplasmic cytotoxic poison. Cyanide ions (CN–) bind to, and inhibit the ferric (Fe3+) heme moiety form of mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase, carbonic anhydrase and other enzyme systems of cellular respiration. This is most rapid of all poisons.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 627

questions.text: In a district hospital, a medical officer is analyzing a case involving a suspicious death. The initial suspicion is of poisoning, and the officer decides to employ specific tests to identify the toxic substance. One of the tests considered is the Lee Jones test. For detecting which substance is the Lee Jones test used?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cyanide

 

Option C:

 

Lee Jones test for gastric aspirate: A few small crystals of ferrous sulfate are added to 5 ml of gastric aspirate, and 4–5 drops of 20% NaOH solution are added to precipitate the iron. The mixture is boiled, cooled and acidified with few drops of 10% HCl. A greenish-blue precipitate (ferricyanide) which intensifies on standing indicates the presence of cyanide.

 

Similar color change may occur with salicylate too.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Carbolic acid: Incorrect. Diagnosis is done by adding 1 ml of 10% ferric chloride to 10 ml of urine; a purple or blue color is formed which persists even on heating.

 

Option B. Arsenic: Incorrect. Arsenic detection typically involves testing of Urine, stool, blood, vomit, hair and nails from patients, and in addition, stomach and intestinal contents, bone, liver, bile and kidneys from dead bodies. Neutron activation analysis and atomic absorption spectroscopy helps in estimating concentration of arsenic in hair, nails and bone.

 

Option D. Lead: Incorrect. Acute mercury poisoning can be detected by measuring blood levels, whereas urine and hair analysis help confirming chronic exposure. Urine and blood mercury levels are assessed by atomic absorption spectrophotometer. Mercury concentration of hair is best assessed by neutron activation analysis

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lee Jones test is used to detect cyanide. This test is part of the investigation process in suspected cases of cyanide poisoning, which can be determined from biological samples collected during the autopsy.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 629

questions.text: During a training session for medical officers in a regional medical college, the discussion turns to the management of cyanide poisoning. A question is raised about the components of a standard cyanide antidote kit. The instructors ask the trainees to identify which substance is NOT typically included in these kits.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sodium bicarbonate

 

Option C:

 

The 3-step cyanide antidote kit (It contains amyl nitrite, sodium nitrite and sodium thiosulfate) –

 

  • 0.3 ml ampule (perles) of amyl nitrite is broken in a gauze and the victim is made to inhale for 30 seconds, every minute (1st step), and use a new perle every 3 min. Stop amyl nitrite, if systolic BP is < 80 mmHg.
  • 10 ml of 3% solution (300 mg) of sodium nitrite is injected IV slowly over 5 min (2nd step),
  • Followed by 50 ml of 25% solution (12.5 g) of sodium thiosulfate over 10–20 min, by the same needle (3rd step).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sodium thiosulfate: Incorrect. This is a key component of the cyanide antidote kit.

 

Option B. Sodium nitrite: Incorrect. It is included in the kit to induce methemoglobinemia.

 

Option D. Amyl nitrite: Incorrect. Amyl nitrite is used for the same purpose as sodium nitrite in the antidote kit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium bicarbonate is not included in a standard cyanide antidote kit. These kits usually contain sodium thiosulfate, sodium nitrite, and amyl nitrite, which are essential in the treatment of cyanide poisoning.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 628

questions.text: In the emergency department of a district hospital, a medical officer is assessing a patient who presents with a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg, cyanosis of the lips and peripheries, and blood that appears chocolate-colored upon drawing. Considering these clinical signs, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methemoglobinemia

 

Option A:

 

A large number of chemical agents are capable of oxidizing ferrous hemoglobin to its ferric state (methemoglobin), a form that cannot carry oxygen and thus inducing a functional anemia. In addition, the shape of oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve is altered, aggravating cellular hypoxia.

 

Drugs and chemicals known to cause methemoglobinemia include benzocaine, antimalarial agents, dapsone, aniline dyes, nitrites, nitrates, nitrogen oxide gas, nitrobenzene, etc.

 

Sign and symptoms –

 

  • The severity of symptoms depends on the percentage of hemoglobin oxidized to methemoglobin; severe poisoning is usually present when methemoglobin fractions are > 40–50%.
  • Even at low levels (15–20%), victims appear cyanotic (especially of the nails, lips and ears), because of the ‘chocolate brown’ color of methemoglobin (‘chocolate cyanosis’), but they have normal PO2 results on arterial blood gas determinations.
  • It may cause dizziness, nausea, headache, dyspnea, confusion, seizures and coma.
  • Severe metabolic acidosis may be present. Hemolysis may occur, especially in patients susceptible to oxidant stress (i.e. those with G-6-PD deficiency).

 

Diagnosis - chocolate brown blood (dry a drop of blood and compare with normal blood).

 

Treatment - High-flow oxygen, activated charcoal, Methylene blue (IV).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hypovolemic shock: Characterized by low blood pressure and signs of poor perfusion but does not typically cause chocolate-colored blood.
 

Option C. Metal fume fever: Associated with inhalation of metal fumes and presents with flu-like symptoms, but not with chocolate-colored blood.
 

Option D. Aluminum phosphide poisoning: Known for severe cardiotoxicity and metabolic acidosis, but it does not present with chocolate-colored blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methemoglobinemia based on its clinical presentation, particularly cyanosis, low blood pressure, and the presence of chocolate-colored blood.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 632-633

questions.text: A forensic expert at a medical college is analyzing a substance retrieved from a residential fire scene. The substance is described as having a waxy texture, emitting a faint glow, and releasing a garlic-like odor. Given these unique properties, the expert is considering the possible identity of this substance. Which poison is most likely being examined?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Yellow phosphorus

 

Option D:

 

White or crystalline Phosphorus Samples always contain some red phosphorus and therefore appear yellow (also called ‘yellow phosphorus’). It is uniquely characterized by its waxy appearance, luminescent quality, and garlic-like smell. These properties are distinctive and significant, particularly in cases involving exposure to incendiary substances.

 

Action: It is a protoplasmic poison and affects cellular oxidation. The metabolism of cells reduces, leading to necrobiosis which is predominantly seen in the liver.

 

Medicolegal aspect - It may be used for homicide purpose by mixing with alcohol or coffee to mask the taste and smell and administered, since symptoms resemble acute liver disease, delay in the appearance of symptoms, poison is oxidized in the body, hence cannot be detected and death occurs after few days. Sometimes, it is taken by mouth or introduced into the vagina to procure abortion.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. Aluminum phosphide: Known for its use as a pesticide, it does not exhibit luminescence or a garlic smell.
 

Option B. Ammonium bromide: Does not have the described physical or olfactory properties.
 

Option C. Opium: Although it has a distinct odor and appearance, it does not glow or smell like garlic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

White (yellow) Phosphorus Vs Red Phosphorus

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 550

questions.text: During an autopsy at a district hospital, a medical officer notes unique findings in a deceased individual suspected of poisoning. There is dark brown staining of the internal organs and a garlic odor emanating from the stomach contents. Based on these autopsy findings, what is the most likely cause of poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phosphorus

 

Option D:

 

The signs of phosphorus poisoning during autopsy, particularly the presence of dark brown internal organ staining and a garlic odor, as key indicators of this type of poisoning.

 

Postmortem Findings –

 

External - Emaciation, purpuric hemorrhages in the skin, jaundice, and smell of garlic may be present. The mucous membrane of the mouth is corroded. Hypostasis is dark brown in color.

 

Internal –

 

  • Multiple hemorrhages are seen in the muscles, serosal and mucosal membranes of the GIT and respiratory tract, liver, kidneys, endocardium, pericardium, epicardium, peritoneum, lungs and brain.
  • Stomach and intestines: Mucous membranes are yellowish or grayish-white in color, softened, thickened, inflamed and corroded in patches; luminous material may be found in the stomach. Contents may smell of garlic.
  • Liver: Swollen, yellow, soft, fatty and easily ruptured.
  • Kidneys: Enlarged, greasy, yellow.
  • Heart: Flabby, pale and shows fatty degeneration.
  • Lungs: Fat emboli may be found in the pulmonary arterioles and capillaries.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hydrocyanic acid: Characteristically produces a bitter almond odor, not a garlic odor.
 

Option B. Carbon dioxide: Does not have a distinct smell and does not cause such staining.
 

Option C. Aniline dye: While it can cause discoloration, it is not associated with a garlic odor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of dark brown staining of internal organs and a garlic odor from the stomach contents is highly indicative of phosphorus poisoning.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 550

questions.text: In a case review involving a snakebite victim, a forensic expert is asked to classify the type of poison based on the clinical symptoms observed. The victim exhibited signs consistent with a specific type of venom. What type of poison is associated with cobra venom?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neurotoxic

 

Option A:


Cobra venom is primarily neurotoxic, affecting the nervous system. It can lead to symptoms such as paralysis, respiratory failure, and, if untreated, death. The neurotoxic effect is the hallmark of cobra venom, making it particularly dangerous. 

 

 

Explanation:
 

Option B. Myotoxic: Causes muscle damage, is primary due to sea snakes.
 

Option C. Cardiotoxic: Also affects the heart, but primarily targets the nervous system.
 

Option D. Vasculotoxic: Targets blood vessels, characteristic effect of viper venom.

 

Educational Objective:


Cobra venom as neurotoxic, primarily leading to severe neurological symptoms in snakebite victims.

 

Cobra Vs viper

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 563

choices.text: Blue line on gums

questions.text: A 50-year-old individual presents to the clinic with nonspecific symptoms including malaise, diffuse abdominal discomfort, and noticeable changes in skin condition. The patient has a history of working in an industry associated with heavy metal use. Physical examination reveals several dermatological and mucosal findings. Based on the history and clinical presentation, you suspect chronic arsenic poisoning. Which of the following findings is least likely to be associated with arsenic poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blue line on gums

 

Option D:

 

Burton’s / Burtonian line: A stippled blue line is seen on the gingival margin in 50–70% cases. It is due to subepithelial deposit of granules at the junction of teeth, especially near dirty or carious teeth of the upper jaw, within a week of exposure. It is due to formation of lead sulphide by the H2S formed from decomposed protein in the mouth. A similar blue line may be seen in cases of poisoning by: Mercury, Iron, Copper, Silver and Bismuth

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Raindrop pigmentation: Characteristic of arsenic poisoning, appearing as dark spots on the skin.

 

 

Option B. Alopecia: Arsenic toxicity can lead to hair loss.
 

Option C. Palmar hyperkeratosis: Thickening of the skin on palms, a common symptom of chronic arsenic exposure.

 

 

Educational Objective:


The dermatological manifestations of chronic arsenic poisoning - Rash resembling fading measles rash, Speckled brown pigmentation, mostly on the skin flexures, temples, shoulders, eyelids and neck (raindrop pigmentation). Macular areas of depigmentation may appear on normal/hyperpigmented skin (leucomelanosis). Hyperkeratosis of the palms and soles with irregular thickening of the nails and development of white bands of opacity in the nails of fingers and toes (called Aldrich-Mees lines). Brittle nails and alopecia are also seen.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 540

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with symptoms that initially resemble a malaria infection. He reports experiencing chills, rigors, and high fever. The patient has no recent travel history to malaria-endemic regions and no known exposure to mosquitoes. Further investigation reveals that he works in an industry with potential exposure to various hazardous materials. Considering the occupational exposure and the nature of his symptoms, which substance is the most likely cause of the poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc

 

Option B:

 

Metal Fume Fever –

 

  • MFF is a self-limiting acute febrile illness associated with inhalation of metal oxide fumes. It is also called smelter’s shakes, brass chills or Monday morning fever.
  • Signs and symptoms: This influenza-like syndrome starts 4–8 h after exposure of fumes, which is characterized by headache, fever, chills, cough, dyspnea, cyanosis, myalgia, metallic taste, salivation, sweating and tachycardia.
  • Symptoms subside within 24–36 h, only to return on repeated exposure.
  • Metals involved: It is caused by acute exposure to fumes/smoke of oxides of zinc (commonest, k/a Zinc shakes - when exposed daily to concentrations of > 8–12 mg/m3), copper, magnesium, nickel, mercury, lead, iron, chromium, cadmium, cobalt, antimony, tungsten, titanium, manganese and silver.
  • A proper occupational history (those involved in welding, melting or flame cutting galvanized metal or in brass foundry operations) should make the diagnosis evident. WBC count may be elevated, chest X-ray is usually normal.
  • Treatment: Supplemental oxygen, bronchodilators (if there is wheezing) and symptomatic treatment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mercury: Causes neurological symptoms, particularly tremors, but not symptoms mimicking malaria.
 

Option C. Red phosphorus: Associated with respiratory irritation and potential burns, not typically presenting with malaria-like symptoms.
 

Option D. Arsenic: Causes gastrointestinal symptoms, skin changes, and neuropathy, but not chills and rigors similar to malaria.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Metal fume fever

 

  • Also known as brass shakes, zinc shakes, metal dust fever, or Monday morning fever,
  •  It is an illness primarily caused by exposure to chemicals such as zinc (most common), aluminum, or magnesium which are produced as byproducts in the fumes that result when certain metals are heated.
  • Welders are commonly exposed to the substances that cause metal fume fever from the base metal, plating, or filler.
  • The signs and symptoms are generally flu-like or malaria like. They include fever, chills, headache, fatigue, muscle aches, joint pains, shortness of breath, pneumonia, chest pain etc. Flu-like symptoms normally disappear within 24 to 48 hours.

 

Mnemonic: ZAM causes metal fume fever (Z for Zinc, A for aluminum, M for magnesium)

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 529

choices.text: Skin may be pinkish or cherry red in color
Erosion and hemorrhages in esophagus and stomach

questions.text: In a case review, a forensic expert is discussing a recent autopsy of an individual who was suspected to have died from poisoning. The case has significant medicolegal implications, and understanding the specific characteristics of various poisons is crucial. The forensic expert is evaluating which features would rule out certain toxins. Which of the following features is not typically associated with cyanide poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Characteristic bitter lemon smell

 

Option A:

 

Postmortem Findings of Cyanide Poisoning

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Congested organs: Incorrect. Congested organs are a common finding in cyanide poisoning due to the profound hypoxia it causes.

 

Option C. Skin may be pinkish or cherry red in color: Incorrect. Cherry red discoloration is commonly associated with CO poisoning, while bright red or bright pink is typically linked to cyanide poisoning. However, these color descriptions are quite similar, making it difficult to distinguish between the two. Although cherry red is most characteristic of CO poisoning, its presence in cyanide poisoning is also a reasonable possibility.

 

Option D. Erosion and hemorrhages in esophagus and stomach: Incorrect. While not as commonly noted as other symptoms, gastrointestinal erosion and hemorrhages can occur in cyanide poisoning, especially if the poison was ingested.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic bitter lemon smell is not typically associated with cyanide poisoning. Cyanide is more commonly described as having a bitter almond odor.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 628-629

questions.text: A medical officer in a district hospital performs an autopsy on a suspected case of poisoning. The deceased had a history of consuming contaminated substances. Considering arsenic as the suspected poison, where would the greatest concentration of arsenic likely be found in the body?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Liver

 

Option C:

 

In the early stage, arsenic is found in greatest quantity in the liver, followed by kidneys and spleen. Arsenic does not cross blood-brain barrier well (brain has lowest level), but inorganic arsenic can cross the placenta. In cases in which life is prolonged, it is found in the muscles for days, in the bones and in the keratin tissues, hair, nails and skin for years. It replaces phosphorus in the bone where it may remain for years.

 

Normally hair contains less than two parts per million arsenic. It can appear in hair and nails within hours of ingestion. Estimates of time of exposure can be made by measuring the distance of Mee's lines from the base of the nails or the length of hair from its growth site.

 

 

In fatal cases, the concentration of arsenic in the liver is usually one mg % or more. Neutron activation analysis and atomic absorption spectroscopy helps in estimating concentration of arsenic in hair, nails, bone, etc.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Muscle: Although arsenic can be found in muscles if life is prolonged, it is not the primary site of accumulation in the early stages of poisoning. Over time, arsenic can be deposited in muscles, but initially, higher concentrations are found in the liver, kidneys, and spleen.

 

Option B. Kidney: The kidneys, along with the liver and spleen, are among the organs where arsenic accumulates in significant amounts in the early stages. However, the liver generally has a higher concentration than the kidneys.

 

Option D. Brain: Arsenic does not cross the blood-brain barrier effectively, resulting in lower levels in the brain compared to other organs. It does, however, cross the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:


Arsenic accumulates predominantly in the liver due to its role in metabolism and detoxification. In cases of arsenic poisoning, the liver often shows the highest concentration of the toxin.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 541

questions.text: In a forensic case review at a medical college, a forensic expert is analyzing a case of suspected carbon monoxide poisoning. The autopsy findings show cherry-red discoloration in the deceased's tissues. The expert is discussing the mechanism of death with the trainee medical officers, emphasizing the specific type of hypoxia caused by carbon monoxide exposure. Understanding this mechanism is crucial for medico-legal reporting. What type of hypoxia is caused by carbon monoxide poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anemic hypoxia

 

Option A:

 

Carbon monoxide poisoning causes anemic hypoxia. This occurs because carbon monoxide binds with hemoglobin in red blood cells more effectively than oxygen, forming carboxyhemoglobin. This reduces the blood's capacity to carry oxygen, leading to tissue hypoxia despite adequate environmental oxygen.

 

Normal COHb level is < 5%, upto 9% in cigarette smokers. Serious toxicity is associated with levels > 25%, and risk of fatality at 70%

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Histotoxic hypoxia: Incorrect. This type occurs when toxins prevent tissues from using oxygen, as seen in cyanide poisoning.

 

Option C. Anoxic hypoxia: Incorrect. Anoxic hypoxia results from a lack of oxygen in the air, not the case in carbon monoxide poisoning.

 

Option D. Stagnant hypoxia: Incorrect. Stagnant hypoxia is caused by poor blood circulation, which is different from the mechanism of carbon monoxide poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carbon monoxid  causes anemic hypoxia by reducing the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.

 

Assessment of severity of CO poisoning  

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 620-621

questions.text: In a district hospital emergency department, a patient is admitted with suspected poisoning following exposure to gas in an enclosed space. The medical officer, after evaluating the patient's symptoms and exposure history, considers the use of hyperbaric oxygen therapy as part of the treatment. In which of the following types of poisoning is orthobaric or hyperbaric oxygen therapy particularly indicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CO poisoning

 

Option D:

 

Orthobaric or hyperbaric oxygen therapy is specifically indicated in cases of carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning. This treatment involves administering oxygen at normal or higher than atmospheric pressures. In CO poisoning, the therapy is beneficial as it enhances the displacement of carbon monoxide from hemoglobin, reducing carboxyhemoglobin levels. This facilitates the faster elimination of carbon monoxide from the body and helps mitigate its toxic effects, particularly on the central nervous system and cardiovascular system.

 

The use of hyperbaric oxygen (HBO) is controversial, as HBO therapy has several disadvantages, such as vomiting, convulsions, agitation, rupture of tympanic membranes, blocked sinuses, etc. HBO has been postulated to reduce the incidence of neurological sequelae. It is indicated in cases of unconsciousness, cardiovascular instability or ischemia, and persistent mental and/or neurologic deficits. HBO at PO2 of 2–3 atmospheric pressure mixed with 5% CO2 may be given through mask or intratracheal tube.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nerve gas: Incorrect. Treatment of nerve gas poisoning primarily involves atropine and pralidoxime, not hyperbaric oxygen.

 

Option B. CO2 poisoning: Incorrect. CO2 poisoning is typically managed by removing the patient from the exposure and providing supportive care, not specifically hyperbaric oxygen therapy.

 

Option C. HCN poisoning: Incorrect. The treatment for cyanide (HCN) poisoning involves specific antidotes like hydroxocobalamin or sodium thiosulfate, not hyperbaric oxygen therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of CO Poisoning - Remove the victim from source of exposure, Maintain patent airway, fresh air and orthobaric oxygen (100% oxygen at atmospheric pressure) by tight-fitting high-flow reservoir face mask or endotracheal tube. The immediate effect of oxygen is enhancement of the dissociation of COHb.; Gastric lavage to prevent aspiration pneumonia.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 622

questions.text: During a forensic medicine conference, a medical officer presents a case involving a deceased individual with distinct cherry-red postmortem staining. This finding prompts a discussion about the toxicological causes of such a presentation. Which of the following substances is most commonly associated with cherry-red postmortem staining?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CO

 

Explanation:

 

Cherry-red postmortem staining is a hallmark feature of carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning. CO binds to hemoglobin, forming carboxyhemoglobin, which imparts a bright red or cherry-red color to the blood and, consequently, to the body tissues. This discoloration is often a key finding in autopsies of individuals who have succumbed to CO poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medicolegal importance: Nature of poisoning and color of postmortem lividity –

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 622

questions.text: In a seminar on chemical warfare and its medicolegal implications, a forensic expert discusses various types of chemical warfare agents. The topic shifts to blistering or vesicant agents used in warfare. To test the participants' knowledge on this subject, the expert asks them to identify the blistering war gas from the given options:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mustard gas

 

Option B:

 

Mustard gas is a well-known blistering or vesicant war gas. It causes severe chemical burns and blisters on the skin and mucous membranes upon exposure. It was widely used during World War I and is considered a chemical weapon due to its ability to cause debilitating injuries.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chlorine gas: Incorrect. Chlorine gas is primarily a choking agent, causing damage to the respiratory system, but it does not cause blistering.

 

Option C. HCN (hydrogen cyanide) gas: Incorrect. Hydrogen cyanide is a blood agent that interferes with cellular respiration but does not cause skin blistering.

 

Option D. Tabun: Incorrect. Tabun is a nerve gas; clinical manifestation are similar to organophosphorus poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vesicants / Blister Gases - Mainly mustard gas (dichlordiethyl sulfide or yperite) and lewisite (dichlorarsine). These are volatile liquids and discharged in artillery shells so as to saturate the area of attack.

 

Treatment - Wash the affected parts thoroughly with soap and water; Wash eyes with sodium bicarbonate solution; and use BAL as an antidote to lewisite.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 625

questions.text: During a lecture focused on the challenges of bioterrorism, you as a forensic expert presents various biological agents that can be used in such attacks. Which of the following is not typically associated with bioterrorism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chicken pox

 

Option B:

 

Chicken pox is not typically associated with bioterrorism. Bioterrorism agents are usually selected for their high mortality rates, ease of dissemination, or potential to cause public panic. Chicken pox, while contagious, does not generally fit the criteria for a bioterrorism agent due to its lower mortality rate and the widespread immunity in the population, either from previous infection or vaccination.

 

Note - Biological weapons are microorganisms or toxins found in nature which can be used to incapacitate, kill or otherwise impede an adversary. Bioterrorism is the deliberate release of viruses, bacteria, toxins or other harmful agents causing illness or death in people, animals or plants.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Clostridia: Some Clostridium species, like Clostridium botulinum, which produces botulinum toxin, are considered potential bioterrorism agents.

 

Option C. Plague: The bacterium Yersinia pestis, is a known potential bioterrorism agent due to its lethality and historical significance.

 

Option D. Ebola virus: Ebola virus is considered a potential bioterrorism agent due to its high mortality rate and severe symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biowarfare Agents - classified under 3 categories by CDC, USA

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 626

questions.text:
A forensic expert in a medical college is investigating a series of poisoning cases in a rural community. Among the substances found at the scene are several insecticides and insect repellents. During the investigation, the forensic expert is providing training to medical officers on distinguishing between different types of compounds commonly used in agriculture and pest control. To test their understanding, the expert presents them with a scenario:

 

A farmer was found unconscious in his storeroom with various chemical containers around him. The medical officers need to identify which one of the listed substances is not an organophosphorus insecticide, as this knowledge is crucial in guiding the treatment of the farmer. Which of the following substances is not an organophosphorus insecticide?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diethyltoluamide (DEET)

 

Option D:

 

Diethyltoluamide (DEET) is not an organophosphorus insecticide. DEET is actually a common active ingredient in many insect repellents but does not belong to the organophosphorus class of insecticides. Organophosphorus insecticides, such as Chlorpyriphos, Gardona (tetrachlorvinphos), and Dimethoate, act by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, leading to the accumulation of acetylcholine at nerve synapses.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chlorpyriphos: Incorrect. Chlorpyriphos is a widely used organophosphorus insecticide.

 

Option B. Gardona (tetrachlorvinphos): Incorrect. Gardona, or tetrachlorvinphos, is an organophosphorus insecticide.

 

Option C. Dimethoate: Incorrect. Dimethoate is another example of an organophosphorus insecticide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classification of the Organophosphorus compounds -

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 520

questions.text: At a rural health center, a medical officer evaluates a farmer who presents with symptoms of confusion, increased salivation, fasciculations, miosis (constricted pupils), tachycardia, and hypertension. Considering the patient's occupation and the symptom profile, the medical officer must determine the most likely cause of these manifestations. Which poison is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) OPC

 

Option B:

 

The symptoms presented by the farmer are characteristic of organophosphorus compound (OPC) poisoning. OPCs are commonly used in agriculture as pesticides. They inhibit acetylcholinesterase, leading to an accumulation of acetylcholine at nerve synapses and neuromuscular junctions. This results in cholinergic symptoms such as increased salivation, fasciculations, miosis, and, in some cases, tachycardia and hypertension.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Opium: Incorrect. Opium typically causes miosis but would also lead to respiratory depression and CNS depression, not the overstimulation seen in this case.

 

Option C. Datura: Incorrect. Datura poisoning usually presents with anticholinergic symptoms like dry mouth, mydriasis (dilated pupils), and tachycardia, which are opposite to the symptoms seen here.

 

Option D. Arsenic: Incorrect. Arsenic poisoning does not typically present with the cholinergic syndrome symptoms seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Signs and symptoms depending on exposure

 

 

*SLUDGE: Salivation, lacrimation, urination, diarrhea, gastrointestinal distress and emesis.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 521

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer arrives at a rural health center with acute onset of symptoms. The medical officer notes that the patient was spraying insecticides in his field earlier in the day. Considering the patient’s occupation and the timing of symptom onset, the medical officer must determine the most likely cause of these manifestations for appropriate management. Which physiological response among the following is not caused by cholinesterase inhibitors, the suspected class of the toxin in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bronchodilation

 

Option B:

 

Cholinesterase inhibitors typically do not cause bronchodilation. Instead, they lead to bronchoconstriction. These inhibitors cause an accumulation of acetylcholine, which stimulates muscarinic receptors leading to effects like increased salivation, miosis, and increased peristalsis. Bronchodilation is more commonly associated with sympathetic nervous system activation or medications that specifically target bronchial smooth muscle relaxation.

 

Severity grading based on cholinesterase levels

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increased salivation: Incorrect. Cholinesterase inhibitors can cause increased salivation due to overstimulation of salivary glands.

 

Option C. Constricted pupils (Miosis): Incorrect. Miosis is a common effect of cholinesterase inhibitors.

 

Option D. Increased peristalsis: Incorrect. Increased gastrointestinal motility, including peristalsis, is a result of cholinesterase inhibitor poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lab. diagnosis of OPC poisoning - based on the depression of cholinesterase activity. In acute poisoning, signs and symptoms generally occur when > 50% of cholinesterase is inhibited.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 521

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer is brought to a rural clinic with acute onset of symptoms including excessive tearing with a distinct pink coloration, known as chromo lacryorrhea. He has a history of working with agricultural chemicals. The medical officer considers various toxic substances that the farmer might have been exposed to. Which of the following substances is most likely associated with chromo lacryorrhea in this case of poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Organophosphorus

 

Option B:

 

Chromolacryorrhea, characterized by pink or red colored tearing, is associated with organophosphorus poisoning. This is due to accumulation of porphyrin in the lachrymal glands is seen very rarely.

 

Sign and Symptoms of OP Poisoning

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cobra: Cobra venom primarily affects the nervous system and blood clotting but does not cause chromolacryorrhea.

 

Option C. Dhatura: Dhatura, a plant with anticholinergic properties, typically causes symptoms like dry mouth and dilated pupils, not chromolacryorrhea.

 

Option D. Carbolic acid: Exposure to carbolic acid can cause local irritation and systemic toxicity, but not chromolacryorrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromolacryorrhea, characterized by pink or red colored tearing, is a unique symptom commonly associated with organophosphorus poisoning. This is due to accumulation of porphyrin in the lachrymal glands is seen very rarely.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 522

choices.text: Pralidoxime, diazepam, atropine, clear airway
Clear airway, atropine, diazepam, pralidoxime
Diazepam, atropine, clear airway, pralidoxime
Atropine, pralidoxime, diazepam, clear airway

questions.text: In an emergency medicine training session, a scenario is presented where a child is suspected to have been poisoned with an organophosphorus compound (OPC). The Resident emphasizes the importance of prioritizing treatment steps in such cases. The trainees are asked to identify the correct order of priority in the management of a child with OPC poisoning:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clear airway, atropine, diazepam, pralidoxime

 

Option B:

 

Treatment of OPC poisoning –

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A, C, D: These options do not prioritize airway management, which is crucial in acute poisoning cases, especially in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of OPC poisoning, the first and foremost step is to ensure a clear airway to maintain oxygenation and prevent aspiration, especially in children. Following airway management, atropine is administered to counteract the muscarinic effects of the poisoning. Diazepam may be used for seizure control or severe agitation, and pralidoxime is given later to reactivate cholinesterase inhibited by the OPC. Pralidoxime decreases the amount of atropine required and also potentiates the action of atropine.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 523

questions.text: A medical officer in a rural clinic encounters a farmer who became unconscious after visiting an orchard. The farmer exhibits symptoms of organophosphorus poisoning, including excessive salivation, constricted pupils, and muscle fasciculations. The medical officer needs to decide on the immediate treatment. What is the first-line treatment in this case of suspected organophosphorus poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atropine

 

Option A:

 

Atropinization: Atropine blocks the muscarinic manifestations and has no effect on nicotinic receptors (on muscle weakness or paralysis) and does not affect the rate of regeneration of inhibited AChE.

 

Dose: 2–4 mg IV (0.05–0.2 mg/kg in children) repeated after every 5–15 minutes (min) till atropinization, the dose should be adjusted to maintain this effect for at least 24 hr (maintenance dose: 0.02–0.05 mg/ kg).

 

Note - Atropine and 2-PAM given together are synergistic against the signs and symptoms of cholinesterase inhibition, thus decreasing atropine requirements.

 

Pralidoxime (2-PAM), a nucleophilic oxime, most effective when treatment is started early and if used within 48 hr, and helps in regenerating AChE associated with skeletal muscle neuromuscular junctions.

 

Dose: 1–2 g IV (20–40 mg/kg) over 5–20 min dissolved in 0.9% normal saline solution, may be repeated at 1–2 hr if muscle weakness is not relieved, and again after 8–10 hr.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Neostigmine:  an anticholinesterase agent, is used to treat neuroparalytic symptoms in cobra envenomation.

 

Option C. Physostigmine: A cholinesterase inhibitor, contraindicated in OPC poisoning.

 

Option D. Adrenaline: Used in anaphylaxis and cardiac arrest, not primary in OPC poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for organophosphorus poisoning is atropine, which is essential for managing muscarinic symptoms such as excessive salivation and bronchial secretions.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 523

questions.text: In a forensic toxicology case review at a medical college, the forensic expert presents a scenario where an individual was accidentally exposed to an insecticide. The individual exhibits symptoms of cholinesterase inhibition, and the medical team is considering the use of cholinesterase reactivators for treatment. The forensic expert emphasizes the importance of identifying the specific class of the insecticide to determine the effectiveness of cholinesterase reactivators. Given this scenario, in which of the following cases would cholinesterase reactivators be ineffective?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Baygon

 

Option A:

 

Cholinesterase reactivators, such as pralidoxime, are used in the treatment of organophosphorus poisoning. However, their effectiveness varies depending on the specific organophosphorus compound involved. Baygon, which is a trade name for the compound propoxur, is a carbamate insecticide. Cholinesterase reactivators are generally ineffective against carbamate poisoning because carbamates form a reversible bond with cholinesterase, unlike the irreversible inhibition caused by organophosphates like parathion, malathion, and Tik 20 (diazinon).

 

Note - The primary mechanism of action of OPCs and carbamates is inhibition of acetylcholinesterase (AChE) and plasma or butyrylcholinesterase (pseudocholinesterase or BuChE) by phosphorylating the serine hydroxyl residue on AChE or BuChE. Hence, these compounds are called cholinesterase inhibitors. It blocks the conversion of acetylcholine to its degradation products—acetic acid and choline.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Parathion: Cholinesterase reactivators can be effective against poisoning by parathion, an organophosphate insecticide.

 

Option C. Malathion: Malathion poisoning can also be treated with cholinesterase reactivators, although its low toxicity to humans often makes severe poisoning less common.

 

Option D. Tik 20: Also known as diazinon, Tik 20 is an organophosphate that can typically be treated with cholinesterase reactivators.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of organophosphorus compound poisoning, the effectiveness of cholinesterase reactivators - Pralidoxime is important. While reactivators can be effective in cases of poisoning by substances like parathion, malathion, and Tik 20, they are less effective against Baygon due to the aging phenomenon.

 

Note - Baygon (aprocarb) is a derivative of Carbonic acid. Organophosphorus insecticides irreversibly inhibit AChE, but carbamates are eliminated rapidly by serum and liver enzymes. Carbamates do not penetrate the CNS to the same extent, resulting in limited CNS toxicity.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 523

questions.text: A patient in the emergency department presents with acute organophosphorus insecticide poisoning. By the third day of treatment, the patient develops ptosis, an inability to lift the head, and difficulty breathing. The medical officer assessing the patient considers these clinical signs to determine the most likely complication that has developed. What is the most likely diagnosis for these symptoms following acute organophosphorus poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intermediate syndrome

 

Option C:

 

Intermediate syndrome (Type II paralysis): It develops in 24–96 hr after resolution of acute cholinergic poisoning symptoms and manifests commonly as paralysis and respiratory distress.

 

Cause: Neuromuscular transmission defect, toxin-induced muscular instability or inadequate treatment of the acute episode.

 

Signs and symptoms: It involves proximal groups of muscle with relative sparing of distal groups and is characterized by cranial nerve palsies, weakness of neck flexors and proximal limb muscles.

 

Treatment: Supportive measures, since it does not respond to oximes or atropine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypokalemia: While it can cause muscle weakness, it does not specifically lead to ptosis or is not a typical consequence of organophosphorus poisoning.

 

Option B. Inflammatory polyneuropathy: This condition develops over a longer period and does not specifically correlate with the acute onset of symptoms post organophosphorus poisoning.

 

Option D. Polymyositis: An inflammatory muscle disease, polymyositis is chronic and not typically associated with organophosphorus poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intermediate syndrome is typically presents within 24-96 hours after acute organophosphorus poisoning and is characterized by muscle weakness affecting the proximal limb muscles, neck flexors, respiratory muscles, and cranial nerve-innervated muscles. This condition is observed due to prolonged cholinesterase inhibition and muscle necrosis. It does not respond to oximes or atropine.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 522

questions.text: A 55-year-old male farmer presents to the emergency department with symptoms of nausea, headache, and confusion. He reports a recent exposure to insecticides in his farm shed. His medical history is unremarkable, and he has no  known allergies. Physical examination reveals mild tremors and ataxia. The medical team considers potential toxicological causes based on the type of insecticides he might have been exposed to. In determining the type of insecticide involved, which of the following substances, known for its neurological effects, is classified as a polychlorinated hydrocarbon?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endrin

 

Option D:

 

Given the farmer's exposure to insecticides and the presentation of neurological symptoms, identifying the type of insecticide is crucial for treatment. Endrin is classified as a polychlorinated hydrocarbon, a group known for causing neurological symptoms such as headache, confusion, tremors, and ataxia. These substances are highly persistent in the environment and can accumulate in the body, leading to chronic toxicity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Parathion: Incorrect. Parathion is an organophosphorus compound and would typically present with cholinergic symptoms, not primarily neurological symptoms.

 

Option B. Malathion: Incorrect. Malathion is also an organophosphorus insecticide and is associated with different toxicological effects.

 

Option C. Diazinon: Incorrect. Diazinon belongs to the organophosphorus class of insecticides and is not a polychlorinated hydrocarbon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endrin is a polycyclic, polychlorinated hydrocarbon belongs to the group of cyclodiene insecticides. It is a stereoisomer of dieldrin. It is also called "plant penicillin", because of its broad spectrum of activity against various insect pests. It is sold in the market under the trade names of Endrin-We-16, Endox-DB 50, Endtox EC-20, Endrex, Tafdrin, etc.

 

Fatal Dose: 5 to 6 g. By ingestion it is 3 time as toxic as aldrin, dieldrin and 10 times as toxic a DDT.

 

Fatal Period: One to several hours.

 

Postmortem Appearances: The mouth and stomach contents smell of kerosene. Signs of asphyxia are present. Endrin resists putrefaction and can be detected in the viscera quite some time after death.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 525

questions.text: A Casulty Medical Officer examines a patient brought in with acute poisoning symptoms. The patient has a distinct garlic odor around the nostrils and mouth. The CMO, recalling the characteristic odors associated with various poisons, considers this a key diagnostic clue. Garlic odor around the nostrils and mouth is indicative of poisoning with which substance?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aluminum phosphide

 

Option D:

 

The presence of a garlic odor around the nostrils and mouth is characteristically associated with aluminum phosphide poisoning. Aluminum phosphide, often used as a fumigant and rodenticide, releases phosphine gas upon exposure to moisture, which has a distinct garlic-like odor. This odor is a crucial diagnostic indicator in cases of suspected aluminum phosphide poisoning.

 

Some important Pointers –

 

  • Aluminium phosphide (ALP) is a solid fumigant pesticide, insecticide and rodenticide.
  • In India it is available as white tablets of Celphos, Alphos, Quickphos, Phostoxin , Phosphotex. etc., each weighing 3 g. and has the capacity to liberate one gram of phosphine (PH3), on coming in contact with moisture.
  • Phosphine is a systemic poison and affects all organs of the body, by inhibiting the respiratory chain enzymes (cytochrome oxidase) and has cytotoxic action.
  • It is widely used as grain preservative.
  • Postmortem Appearances: Garlic-like odour is present at the mouth and nostrils and in the gastric contents. Blood-stained froth is found in the mouth and nostrils
  • Diagnosis - The most specific and sensitive method for detecting phosphine is gas chromatography with a nitrogen-phosphorous detector (gastric contents and viscera during autopsy are collected in air tight jars).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cyanide: Incorrect. Cyanide poisoning is typically associated with the smell of bitter almonds, not garlic.

 

Option B. Organophosphorus: Incorrect. Organophosphorus compounds typically emit Kerosene-like odor.

 

Option C. Carbolic acid: Incorrect. Carbolic acid (phenol) has a distinct medicinal or tar-like odor, not garlic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Smell due to various poisons

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 527

choices.text: Reduction of organ toxicity and correction of arrhythmias
Enhancement of phosphine excretion
Prevention of gastric acidity and liberation of phosphine gas
Correction of metabolic acidosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to a district hospital, after a suspected suicide attempt with a substance known to be used as a rodenticide. The medical officer diagnoses alphos (aluminum phosphide) poisoning. In the treatment protocol, magnesium sulfate is administered. What is the primary role of magnesium sulfate in the treatment of alphos poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reduction of organ toxicity and correction of arrhythmias

 

Option A:

 

Magnesium sulfate in the treatment of alphos poisoning is primarily used for reducing organ toxicity and correcting arrhythmias (helps in managing the cardiac complications). It has an antiperoxidant effect and combats free radical stress due to phosphine.

 

Dose: 3gm bolus followed by 6gm as infusion over 12 hr for 5–7 days; or 

 

3gm as infusion over 3 hr followed by 6 gm every 24 hr for 3–5 days.

 

Treatment of aluminum phosphide poisoning

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Enhancement of phosphine excretion: Phosphine is excreted through the lungs and kidneys, and while adequate hydration and diuretics like furosemide can be used, magnesium sulfate does not play a direct role in enhancing phosphine excretion.

 

Option C. Prevention of gastric acidity and liberation of phosphine gas: Antiemetics and H2 receptor antagonists are used for this purpose, not magnesium sulfate.

 

Option D. Correction of metabolic acidosis: Metabolic acidosis in alphos poisoning is typically addressed with sodium bicarbonate IV, not magnesium sulfate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Magnesium sulfate in the treatment of alphos poisoning is primarily used for reducing organ toxicity and correcting arrhythmias.

 

Some Important Pointers related to Treatment - 

 

  • No specific antidote; focus on intensive care.
  • Maintain blood pH, electrolytes, and blood pressure.
  • Resuscitation of shock - Hydrocortisone, dopamine, Norepinephrine, Digoxin for cardiogenic shock.
  • Correction of metabolic acidosis - Sodium bicarbonate, hemodialysis
  • For GIT - Gastric lavage with KMnO4; activated charcoal; antacids and liquid paraffin.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 528

questions.text: In a clinical scenario at a hospital, a 26-year-old woman named Lalita is brought to the emergency department after ingesting 100 tablets of paracetamol (acetaminophen). The medical team, led by an emergency medicine physician, assesses the situation and must quickly decide on the most appropriate treatment for this case of acute paracetamol overdose. Considering the potential for severe liver damage in such a scenario, what is the treatment of choice for Lalita?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acetylcysteine

 

Option D:

 

The treatment of choice for a paracetamol (acetaminophen) overdose is Acetylcysteine. Acetylcysteine acts as a precursor for glutathione, which is essential for detoxifying the harmful metabolite (NAPQI) produced by paracetamol metabolism, especially in overdose situations. Administering Acetylcysteine early, preferably within 8-10 hours of ingestion, is crucial to prevent or minimize liver damage.

 

Dose - 150 mg/kg in 200 ml of 5% glucose over 15 minutes (min), followed by serial infusion of 50 mg/kg in 500 ml of 5% glucose in 4, 8 and 8 hr (total 300 mg/kg in 20 hr) or 140 mg/kg orally as loading dose, followed by 70 mg/kg every 4 hr.

 

Signs and symptoms of PCM poisoning

 

 

*Death usually occurs in stage III. If not, then patient passes into stage IV.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lavage with charcoal: Incorrect. While gastric lavage and activated charcoal can be used in the initial management of an overdose, they are not the definitive treatments for paracetamol toxicity.

 

Option B. Dialysis: Incorrect. Dialysis is not typically the first-line treatment for paracetamol overdose unless there is severe renal failure or severe acid-base or electrolyte abnormalities.

 

Option C. Alkaline diuresis: Incorrect. Alkaline diuresis is not a standard treatment for paracetamol overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of PCM Poisoning –

 

  • Activated charcoal and gastric lavage within 1–2 hr of ingestion.
  • Antidote: N-acetyl cysteine (NAC). Administration of NAC within 8 hr of ingestion is nearly 100% hepatoprotective.
  • Supportive measures: Intravenous electrolytes, rehydration, vitamin K for bleeding, and mannitol for cerebral edema.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 631

questions.text: In a toxicology lecture, the focus is on the management of various poisonings. A case study is presented where a patient has ingested a significant amount of iron. The medical officer leading the lecture asks the attendees to identify the treatment option that is not used for iron poisoning. Which of the following is NOT used for treating iron poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Penicillamine

 

Option D:

 

Penicillamine is not typically used for the treatment of iron poisoning. It is a chelating agent more commonly used in the treatment of copper poisoning, such as in Wilson's disease, and heavy metal poisoning like lead or mercury, but not iron.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Magnesium hydroxide: Incorrect. Magnesium hydroxide can be used as an antacid and laxative to reduce iron absorption.

 

Option B. Desferrioxamine: Incorrect. Desferrioxamine is a specific chelating agent used to treat acute iron poisoning.

 

Option C. Gastric lavage: Incorrect. Gastric lavage can be used in the initial management of iron poisoning to remove unabsorbed iron from the stomach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Appropriate management of iron poisoning - Treatment is usually whole-bowel irrigation and chelation therapy.

 

  • Fluid resuscitation: Normal saline drip or lactated Ringer's solution.
  • Decontamination: Gastric lavage or whole bowel irrigation with normal saline or polyethylene glycol-electrolyte solution.
  • Chelation therapy: Desferrioxamine (antidote)

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 631

questions.text: In a medical emergency training session, a scenario is presented where a woman has consumed several tablets of amitriptyline, an antidepressant. The trainers are discussing the appropriate management steps for a tricyclic antidepressant overdose. They ask the trainees to identify which of the following actions is not recommended in this situation. All of the following can be done in the case of amitriptyline overdose, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atropine as antidote

 

Option D:

 

Atropine is not used as an antidote in the case of amitriptyline overdose. Amitriptyline overdose can lead to anticholinergic symptoms, for which atropine would be contraindicated as it is also an anticholinergic agent.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. NaHCO3 (Sodium Bicarbonate): Incorrect. Sodium Bicarbonate is used in tricyclic antidepressant overdose to treat cardiac toxicity.

 

Option B. Gastric lavage: Incorrect. Gastric lavage can be considered for decontamination if the patient presents early after the overdose.

 

Option C. Diazepam for seizures: Incorrect. Diazepam may be used to manage seizures which can occur in tricyclic antidepressant overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine is contraindicated in amitriptyline overdose due to its anticholinergic properties, which could exacerbate anticholinergic symptoms. But Sodium Bicarbonate is used for cardiac toxicity, Gastric lavage for early decontamination, and Diazepam for seizure management in amitriptyline overdose.

 

Medico-legal aspects: Poisoning with amitriptyline overdose is frequent with suicidal attempts by depressed individuals.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 594

questions.text: A casualty medical officer is evaluating a young adult brought to the emergency department with a sudden loss of consciousness at a social gathering. The patient's friends suspect that something might have been added to the patient's drink. The medical officer considers the possibility of a drug-facilitated crime. Which of the following substances, known for being used in such scenarios, is commonly referred to as "knockout drops"?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chloral hydrate

 

Option B:

 

Knock-out drops or Mickey Finn is a drink adulterated with a psychoactive drug (especially chloral hydrate) given to someone without their knowledge, to potentiate intoxication with intent to incapacitate them. This can help to facilitate robbery, rape, etc. as it makes their victims helpless

 

 Chloral hydrate:

 

  1. Chloral hydrate is a sedative and hypnotic
  2. It is a white crystalline substance with a pungent, pear-like odor and bitter taste.
  3. Chloral hydrate is rarely used as a hypnotic today, but is commonly used to adulterate drinks (Mickey Finn or Knock-out drops).
  4. It is also called dry wine

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Paraldehyde: While used as a sedative and anticonvulsant, paraldehyde is not commonly known as "knockout drops" and is less likely to be used in the context of a drug-facilitated crime.

 

Option C. Kerosene: This is a petroleum product used as a fuel and not associated with drug-facilitated crimes or sedation.

 

Option D. Turpentine: A solvent used primarily in paint thinners; turpentine is not known as "knockout drops" nor is it associated with such criminal use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classification of poisons based on their effect/outcome

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 590

questions.text: A forensic expert is called to assess a case at a district hospital where an individual has been brought in with signs of drug withdrawal. The patient exhibits various symptoms, and the medical officer is considering opioid withdrawal as a differential diagnosis. Based on the expert's knowledge of opioid withdrawal symptoms, which of the following is not typically associated with opioid withdrawal?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hallucinations

 

Option B:

 

Hallucinations are not typically a feature of opioid withdrawal. Opioid withdrawal is characterized by physical symptoms due to the body's adaptation to the absence of the opioid. Typical symptoms include nausea, vomiting, anorexia, sweating, diarrhea, yawning, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, tachycardia, pupillary dilatation, insomnia, muscle cramps, generalized body ache, anxiety, piloerection (goose skin), and mild elevation of blood pressure, body temperature, and respiratory rate.

 

Hallucinations are more characteristic of alcohol withdrawal and are not a standard feature in the withdrawal from opioids like heroin or morphine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Yawning: Incorrect. Yawning is a common symptom observed during opioid withdrawal.

 

Option C. Lacrimation: Incorrect. Excessive tearing or lacrimation is a characteristic symptom of opioid withdrawal.

 

Option D. Piloerection: Incorrect. Piloerection, or goosebumps, is a typical symptom during the withdrawal phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Characteristic symptoms of opioid withdrawal - Nausea, vomiting, anorexia, sweating, diarrhea, yawning, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, tachycardia, pupillary dilatation, insomnia, muscle cramps, generalized body ache, anxiety, piloerection (goose skin), and mild elevation of blood pressure, body temperature and respiratory rate.

 

The heroin withdrawal syndrome is more severe than that of morphine.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 580

questions.text: At a district hospital, a medical officer is called to assist in a medicolegal case involving a young adult found unconscious in an alley with evidence of drug use. Suspecting opioid overdose as a possible cause, the medical officer also considers the potential for substance abuse treatment history in the individual's background. While evaluating the medications and substances found at the scene, the medical officer must determine which of them is not typically used in the treatment of heroin detoxification. This information is crucial for both the medical management of the patient and the ongoing forensic investigation. Which of the following substances is not used for the treatment of heroin detoxification?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Disulfiram

 

Option A:
